4566055/4562745/4569560.title: Scéal faoi Mhicheál Ó Casaigh agus Jack o' the Lantern
4566055/4562745/4569560.text:
Iascaire a béadh é agus ní raibh sé ar breith ar aon ceó ach bhí sé in a snaimheóir maith agus cuimnigh sé ar a cuidh éadaigh a bhaint dhó agus dul faoi an uisge ag breith ar na heisc.Rinne sé dul faoí an uisge ach ní raibh sé ag breith ar na héisc
(continues on next page)

4566057/4563151/4570860.title: Ainmhithe Allta
4566057/4563151/4570860.text:
Ainmhidhthe AlltaNil mórán ainmhidhthe allta thart san át seo.  Tá sionnaigh, girrfiadhthe, coinníní, easóa agus correasóg ruadh.  Siad na sionnaigh agus na girriadhthe is tuigha atá ann.  Comhnuigheann na sionnaidh i bpollaibh sa talamh.  Itheann na coinníní cabáiste agus duilleóga glasa, agus goideann na sionnaigh cearca agus lachain lén ithe dóibh féin.  Fanann na girrciadhthe amuigh ins na páirceanna in áit a bhfuil na rannóig agus na sgeacha agus itheann siad an féar glas.  Marbhuigheaann na h-easóga
(continues on next page)

4566058/4563294/4570881.title: Names of Wild Animals in the District
4566058/4563294/4570881.text:
Names of wild animals in the district.1.  The fox.2.  The rabbit.3.  The hare.4.  The badger.5.  The weasel.6.  The rat7.  The ferritThe fox.The fox is said to be the cleverest animal on earth.  It is a very swift runner and few hounds are able to keep up with it.It lives in a big burrow called a den under the ground.  When the hounds follow it, it runs into this hole for safety.  It's food chiefly consists of hens, ducks geese, turkeys and lambs.  It does a great deal of damage on the farmer because it steals a lot of his fowl.Many men follow it trying to shoot it because its skin makes a lovely fur for a woman's
(continues on next page)

4566058/4563296/4570886.title: The Rabbit
4566058/4563296/4570886.text: The rabbit is another wild animal. It is like a cat and about the same size.Its food consists of green grass and turnips. On this account it does a lot of damage on the farmer because it eats a great deal of his turnips.Its meat is very sweet and nearly everybody likes it. Rich men shoot it for food. A burrow is is dwelling place.

4566058/4563297/4570891.title: The Hare
4566058/4563297/4570891.text: There is another animal like the rabbit called the hare. It is a very swift runner.   People around here say that it is unlucky to have anything to do with it.Its food consists of grass and turnips. Nobody likes its meat for food. It lives in ferns and long grass.

4566058/4563298/4570893.title: The Badger
4566058/4563298/4570893.text: There lives in the woods of Pollnahalia, Caherlistrane, Co. Galway a small animal like a young pig called the badger. It is a very wicked little animal and it would attack you without much cause. It is impossible to shoot without leaving the barrel of he gun on its skin for it is very tough. It eats roots of young ash trees and it lives under the bushes. Its bite is poisonous.

4566058/4563299/4570897.title: The Weasel
4566058/4563299/4570897.text: Another common animal in the district of Caherlistrane is the weasel. It's chief food is rabbits. It lives in a burrow in the ground.The rat.There is another animal like the weasel called the rat. It destroys a lot of the farmers corn when they have it in bags in the barn. On this account they hate it and they often try to do away with it by poisoning or trapping it. It lives in a hole in the wall.

4566058/4563300/4570899.title: The Ferret
4566058/4563300/4570899.text: In some parts of the country people keep ferrits. They are very useful animals for they would go into a burrow and kill all the rabbits they would come up to. A wild one is very wicked and it would kill a great deal of hens and ducks.There are very few wild ones to be seen.Some of the old people in Caherlistrane say that there is a cure in the food it leaves after it for the whooping cough.

4566079/4565252/4571850.title: Ainmhithe Allta
4566079/4565252/4571850.text:
In the olden days animals were plenty in Ireland, The king and his court used to go out hunting for boars in the woods or in the forests. The elk was one of the biggest animals in the world.
(continues on next page)

4566079/4565253/4571851.title: Wild Animals
4566079/4565253/4571851.text:
(continued from previous page)
The king and his court loved hunting in the woods. The people in the olden times were skilled at hunting. The boar's home was a hole in the ground. The boar was very wise and when he dug the hole he covered it with grass so that it was unseen to the eyes of man. The fox was a clever fellow also and the hunters loved hunting him because he could run a great distance and he used all his tricks to outwit the horsmen. His food was a chiken or a hen that he stole during the night on some poor person.



Seo cuid des na h-ainmhidhte Allta atá le fagáil in aice Connde na Gaillimh. An sionnach an an deorug agus an firéad. Comhnuigheann na h-ainmidhthe seo i
(continues on next page)

4566066/4563998/4571986.title: Wild Animals
4566066/4563998/4571986.text:
There are many wild animals in this district such as the fox, rabbit, hare, waterdog and mouse. The fox generally make its nests in among the furs. He is very wise because he kills hens, ducks and geese at night. It is also said that there is a cure in a fox's tongue. When the foxes are killed many people cure their skin and make nice furs of them. The rabbit generally makes its burrows in the ground and in the ditches. He destroy's the crops and he also eats some of the seed. The hare generally make its burrow in the ground and in the ditches. He also destroys the crops and eats some of the seed like the rabbit.
(continues on next page)

4566082/4565520/4572554.title: Ainmhithe Allta
4566082/4565520/4572554.text:
Níor chuala mé go raibh mórán  ainmhidhe allta ar an mbaile fadó ach amháin an sionnach,an bruc agus an girrfidh . Tá siad ann fós freisin.Pluais a bhíos ag an sionnach agus an bruc. Nior cualas an sgéul faoi gliceas an t-sionnaigh na an girrfiadh. Ach chualas go bhfuil leigheas acu mar nuair a beireann siad an sionnach baintear an teanga as mar deirtear go bhfuil sé go maith le dealg a thabhairt ar do cois nó do laimh.Ainmidhe beag nimneach eile is ead an firréad. An cuid dén baille a d'fhágffadh sé in a dhiaidh tá leigheas acu freisin  déarfaidís go bhfuilsé go maithe le haghaidh an truich.Níl mórán Ainmidhe allta in mo baile féin anois ach seo na cinn is mó le rádh ann: - An mada ruadh. Tá sé an-a ghlic ar fad agus is minic a thug sé cearca ó na daoine agus isis minic a bhíos daoine ar a thoir agus madaidh acu. An Girrfidh, tá sé an-mhear agus ní déanann sé aon diogbhail ach mar sin fein marbhuigheann na doine iad. Is ins na sgeacha a chomnuigeas siad. An Broc, bíonn bola bréan air agus tá se chomh roighin le seilimide. An Easóg, ainmhidhe beag ruadh a bhfuil dúil
(continues on next page)

4562128/4562070/4572994.title: A Story about a Rat and a Weasel
4562128/4562070/4572994.text: Long ago the old men used to wear low shoes, long stockings and short pants, and one day an old man was ploughing in a field, and a rat and a weasel had a great fight, and he was a long time looking at them. At last the rat was getting the better hand of him and he went to save the weasel, and when he went to save him, the rat bit him in the leg. Next day his foot was swelled up and he was not able to anything. That morning the weasel came to the door with a leaf in his mouth, the people of the house undertook that it must be for to put with the foot, because he saved him. So he put it with the foot, and next morning it was better. The old people say that it is not right to do anything on a weasel and if you do anything on him he will do something on you a short time afterwards.

4566083/4565665/4573393.title: Ainmhithe Allta
4566083/4565665/4573393.text:
An SionnachTá go leor ainmhidhthe Allta thart orm. Ta go leor sionnach, broc, girrfhiadhtha, coiníní, easóga agus firéad.Chonnaic mé sionnach go minic. Comhnuigheann sé i mbruchais faoi an talamh. Bíonn leaba aige agus bíonn sé déanta de raithne. Marbhuigheann sé coinníní le nithe. Nuair a bhíos ocras mór air goideann sé cearca agus lochain ó na feilméaraibh. Tá go leor sgéaltaí ag baint leis an sionnach agus an gcaoi ar imir sé a cuid cleasanna.An BrocChonaic me an broc go minic. Tá sé timcheall is chomh mór leis an sionnach. Comhnuigheann sé i sgailp clochach. Bíonn leaba aige agus bíonn sé déana de sean-fhéar. Marbhuigheann se coiníním cearca agus éanacha beag le n-ithe. An GirrfhiadhChonnaic mé an girrfhiadh go minic. Tá sé níos mó ná an coinín. Dath dhonn a bhíos orra. Comhnuigheann sé ar an móin agus ar na ceagrachaibh. Bíonn nead aige ins an bhféar fada nó i dtom dirseacha/ Itheann sé slochtán agus clóbhar. Bíonn daoine gá bhfiadhach le conaibh agus bíonn spóirt mór aca.
(continues on next page)

4566083/4565668/4573394.title: Scéalta ag Baint le hAinmhithe Allta
4566083/4565668/4573394.text:
Bhí sionnach ann uair amháin agus oidhche an dorcha tháinig sé go cró na gcearc agus chuaidh sé isteach i bpoll a bhí ann agus thosuigh sé ag marbhughadh na gcearc. Ar maidin nuair a tháinig an feilméar amach leis na cearca a leigint amach bhí siad ar fad marbh agus an sionnach ina luighe mar a bheadh sé caillte in aice leo. Rug an feilméar ar ruball an tsionnaigh agus thug sé cúpla cic dhó agus caith sé amach ar an gcarn aoilig é. Annsin d'éirigh an sionnach agus rith sé leis.



Bhí Sionnach ag siubhal thart lá agus casadh portán leis. Bhí siad ag siubhal le chéile agus thosuigh an sionnach ag caitheamh droch-mheasa ar an bportán agus ars' an sionnach "Níl a bhfhios agam an ar do chúl no ar t'aghaidh nó i n-aghaidh do thaoibhe atá tú ag siubhal". "A shionnaigh na gcrúb" a deir an portán, "cuirfidh mé giní go scoithfidh mé thú i rása míle". Chuir an sionnach giní eile nach scoithfeadh. Thosuigh siad ag rith. As go bráthach leis an sionnach. Thug an portán léim agus chuaidh sé i bhfastódh in earball an tsionnaigh agus bhí sé ag imteacht gur tháinig sé go cloich an míle. Chas sé go tapaidh go bhfeicfeadh sé cá raibh an portán. Léim an portán as a earball
(continues on next page)

4566083/4565668/4573395.title: Scéalta ag Baint le hAinmhithe Allta
4566083/4565668/4573395.text:
Bhí sionnach ann uair amháin agus oidhche an dorcha tháinig sé go cró na gcearc agus chuaidh sé isteach i bpoll a bhí ann agus thosuigh sé ag marbhughadh na gcearc. Ar maidin nuair a tháinig an feilméar amach leis na cearca a leigint amach bhí siad ar fad marbh agus an sionnach ina luighe mar a bheadh sé caillte in aice leo. Rug an feilméar ar ruball an tsionnaigh agus thug sé cúpla cic dhó agus caith sé amach ar an gcarn aoilig é. Annsin d'éirigh an sionnach agus rith sé leis.



Bhí Sionnach ag siubhal thart lá agus casadh portán leis. Bhí siad ag siubhal le chéile agus thosuigh an sionnach ag caitheamh droch-mheasa ar an bportán agus ars' an sionnach "Níl a bhfhios agam an ar do chúl no ar t'aghaidh nó i n-aghaidh do thaoibhe atá tú ag siubhal". "A shionnaigh na gcrúb" a deir an portán, "cuirfidh mé giní go scoithfidh mé thú i rása míle". Chuir an sionnach giní eile nach scoithfeadh. Thosuigh siad ag rith. As go bráthach leis an sionnach. Thug an portán léim agus chuaidh sé i bhfastódh in earball an tsionnaigh agus bhí sé ag imteacht gur tháinig sé go cloich an míle. Chas sé go tapaidh go bhfeicfeadh sé cá raibh an portán. Léim an portán as a earball
(continues on next page)

4566083/4565669/4573396.title: Scéalta ag Baint le hAinmhithe Allta
4566083/4565669/4573396.text:
(continued from previous page)
suas leis ar an gcloich. "Cé l aghaidh a bhfuil tú ag féachaint ansin" adeir an portán. "Tá mé ag fanacht leat annseo le fada ach bhí an geall caillte ag an sionnach.



Bhí sionnach ag rubhal thart lá in-aice leis a táoiller agus bhí go leor báirneach ann. Bhí an táoille ag teacht isteach agus thoruigh na bháirnighe ag oscailt.Chonnaic an sionnach ceann aca ag ocailt agus thoruigh sé dá lighe agus dairigh an bháirneach é agus dún sé isteach arís agus níor fhéad an sionnach a theannga a tharraingt ar. Da ghearr gur thainig an caoille isteach agus báitheadh é.



Bhí beirt fhear ag baint féin lá agus fuair  siad easóg agus coinín aice agus bhain siad dí an coinín. Bhí crúiscín aca a raibh deoch ann agus chuaidh sí go dtí é agus  caith sí smugairle síos ann. Chaith riahb aice an coinín arís agus d'imtigh leithe agus dóirt sí an crúiscín a raibh an tuirge ann.

4566083/4565669/4573397.title: Scéalta ag Baint le hAinmhithe Allta
4566083/4565669/4573397.text:
(continued from previous page)
suas leis ar an gcloich. "Cé l aghaidh a bhfuil tú ag féachaint ansin" adeir an portán. "Tá mé ag fanacht leat annseo le fada ach bhí an geall caillte ag an sionnach.



Bhí sionnach ag rubhal thart lá in-aice leis a táoiller agus bhí go leor báirneach ann. Bhí an táoille ag teacht isteach agus thoruigh na bháirnighe ag oscailt.Chonnaic an sionnach ceann aca ag ocailt agus thoruigh sé dá lighe agus dairigh an bháirneach é agus dún sé isteach arís agus níor fhéad an sionnach a theannga a tharraingt ar. Da ghearr gur thainig an caoille isteach agus báitheadh é.



Bhí beirt fhear ag baint féin lá agus fuair  siad easóg agus coinín aice agus bhain siad dí an coinín. Bhí crúiscín aca a raibh deoch ann agus chuaidh sí go dtí é agus  caith sí smugairle síos ann. Chaith riahb aice an coinín arís agus d'imtigh leithe agus dóirt sí an crúiscín a raibh an tuirge ann.

4566058/4563339/4573447.title: Names of the Wild Animals of the District
4566058/4563339/4573447.text: The fox the hare and the rabbit are the wild animals of this district.The fox lives in a den or a hole between two stones. It does a lot of damage for it steals hens and foul and young lambs and eats them. Some people hunt it to get its skin. The skin is cured and made into beautiful furs which the women wear nowadays.The hare is a very swift runner and very few people like it because its flesh is not nice to eat. It destroys cabbage, turnips and sometimes potatoes. It lives in a burrow or hole in the ground. The rabbit is much like the hare, but its flesh is nice to eat. It, also, destroys the crops and the corn. It lives in a burrow or hole also.

4569051/4566988/4574146.title: The Weasel
4569051/4566988/4574146.text: One day a man named Patsy Michall was cutting hay with a scythe. He came across a weasel's nest with four young ones in it. He shifted the nest out of his way, but did not harm the young weasels. When the old weasel returned and found that her nest had been interfered with she was very angry. As was the custom the man had taken a drink of white water in a jug with him, and had left it in the headland What was his surprise when he saw the weasel going over to the jug, and spitting into the jug. It was then he knew the mistake he had made in interfering with the weasels nest. So he took the the nest and returned it to the very spot from which he had taken it. He then went home to his dinners, and when he came back he noticed the weasel again at the jug. What she was doing was trying to spill the drink which contained her spit as it was poisin. This was in return for the man leaving back her nest. This man is still living.

4569043/4566250/4574275.title: Ainmhithe Allta
4569043/4566250/4574275.text:
Ta ainmhidhthe allta thart fá'n áit seo. Tá coiníní, girrfhiadhthe, bruic, sionnaigh agus easóga in n-a gcomhnuidhe  san áit seo. Tá go leór (sionnaigh) sionnach i n-Árd Fhraoigh agus déanann siad a lán díoghbhála. Téigheann daoine ar a dtóir uaireanta agus marbhuigheann said cuid aca. Tá teanga an t-sionnaigh go maith chun dealg do tharraingt amach. Is ainmhidhe beag í an easóg. Déanann sí  a lán díoghbhála acht tá maitheas inntí freisin. Tá a lán sgéalta faoi díoghaltas na h-easóige. Aon lá amháin bhí fear ag  siubhal go dtí an Ghaillimh. Chonaic sé frannchac agus easóg  ag troid le chéile. Thug an fear buille do'n francach agus bhain an franncach greim ar a chois. Annsin chuaidh an fear abhaile agus an chéad lá eile ní raibh sé indon siubhal leis an pian a bhí i na chois. An oidhche sin rith an easóg isteach agus d'fhág sí duilleabhar de crann in aice leis. Chuir an fear an duilleabhar leis an áit i na chos a raibh an pian agus leighiseadh é.



Tá go leor leighis ag na sean daoine thart fá'n dúthaigh seo. Tá áit i mBaile na Cloiche agus bhíodh naomh i na luighe ann gach oidhche agus bhíodh  tinneas fiacla uirthí go minic agus dhá mbeadh tinneas fiacla ar duine agus dá gchodlóchadh an duine (ar) sin san
(continues on next page)

4583276/4575890/4583428.title: Bird-Lore
4583276/4575890/4583428.text:
The RobinThe color of the robin of is brown and it has a red breast. Long ago when the soldiers were crucifying our Lord, the robin tried to to pull the thorns from His head. Drops of blood fell off the robin's breast. it builds its nest with moss and horsehair. It four or five eggs.The WrenThere are lore stories told of the wren. When St. Stephen was hiding from the soldiers he climbed a tree. As the soldiers were passing beneath a wren on a higher branch started to sing - this caused the soldiers to look up and immediately St. Stephen was discovered. This account for the wren - boys as St. Stephen's Day. The other - as the robin brought moss for our Lord's wounds the of wren took it to build its nest.The BlackbirdBuilds its nest with moss. Lays five eggs which are blue with black spots. The KoructakeMakes her nest in the grass. Lays five eggs.The CrowBuilds her of sticks and lay on top of a high tree. It lays five blue eggs spotted with white.
(continues on next page)

4569059/4567906/4583441.title: A Story
4569059/4567906/4583441.text:
(continued from previous page)
years last New Years night a man named Bat Mullins of "Leathcoill" was returning from a visit very late. He saw a lot of athletes playing football in that field. They could run as swiftly as a deer and could jump a great height. This was very late. He saw another man and he called him but they suddenly vanished out of his sight, and the other man could not see them at all. Collected by Patrick Melia From my father.



Once upon a time there were men working in a hay field. Near the crossroad of Gurteen they were working. They had a can of milk with them to drink on account of the weather been
(continues on next page)

4583359/4582985/4583695.title: Ainmhithe Allta
4583359/4582985/4583695.text: Seo iad na h ainmhidhthe atá ar fághail fiadhain tart annseo - an coinín agus an girrfhiadh. Shuas ar an sliabh is mo a bhíonn siad acht tagann coinín anois agus arist anuas cois fhairrge acht ní fada a mhaireann siad ann mar tá madraí go leor thart.Níl tuairisg ag aoinne faoi broc a bheith thart ann ariamh. Thagadh madaruadh "ar cuairt" anuas ón sliabh mórán blianta ó choin acht is fada ó chuir aon cheann aca isteach ar an áit anois. Ní chuireann an cor choinín tada as do na feilméaraí annseo agus is annamh anois a theigheann na buachaillí ag fiadhach mar theighidis fadó mar ní fiú dhóibh.Úasáidtear teanga an t sionnaigh chun leighis agus teigheann daoine i bfad ó bhaile ar lorg ceann.

4583279/4576123/4585680.title: Bird-Lore
4583279/4576123/4585680.text: Bird Lore The birds that are most common in my village are the plover, robin and swallow. The plover builds her nest on a little hill. She makes her nest in a little hole in the ground and lines it with grass. She lays four blue eggs. She hatches them for a fortnight. The robin makes her nest in a bush, she lays five white eggs and hatches for three weeks. It is said that she tried to pick the thorms from our lords head and a drop of blood fell on its breast and that it is why it has a red breast. The swallow builds her nest on the eveshoots of houses. She builds it of mud and lines it with hay. She lays six eggs and she hatches them for a fortnight.There are a lot of wild birds in the lake nearby. There are wild duck and water hens, swans and baldcoots.The wild duck makes her nest of rushes and lays 12 eggs. The eggs are the size of a tame duck's egg but are speckled. She hatches for a month. The swan makes a very big nest of rushes and flaggers, She lays three eggs and hatches for five weeks. Una EganCalla,Kilconnell

4583271/4575353/4585862.title: Áitainmneacha
4583271/4575353/4585862.text:
(continued from previous page)
field, the limekiln field. These are so named because such things exist in the fields named after them. Another section of the farm is called moon and I think it is so named because of the great amount of moss which grows in it. The land adjoining it continues under the name of moon and also, although that portion is in possession of other people. In ancient times butter and other provisions are supposed to be hid there.



''There are not very many different kinds of wild animals in this district nowadays, principally because the woods are almost cut  away.  The wild animals I know of are, hares, rabbits, rats, weasles, foxes, squirrels, hedgehogs, and wild cats.  All those animals do a certain amount of destruction in the district of late years, especially because the farmers cultivate more tillage than years ago.    Rabbits ruin the beet-crop in
(continues on next page)

4583271/4575379/4585981.title: Áitainmneacha
4583271/4575379/4585981.text:
(continued from previous page)
ner of it. The tillage field is so called because it is tilled every year.



The names of the wild animals in my district are. The rabbits, hares, foxes, and weasles.  The hares and rabbits make their nests in a ditch.  When they are living in a small while there they bore a big hole from one side to the other through the ditch in order to escape when danger. The fox makes his nest through furs. The fox does a lot of harm when the little lambs are born.     The rabbit do no good but all the harm they do. They destroy the crops and make very big holes in the ditches.The weasles destroy the cabbage sometimes and where the weasle is you will see no rat.



There is not many tailors in my parish nowadays.  I only know one tailor in my parish.  His name is Patrick Connelly.  He works in his own house and the clothes is brought to him.  He does not keep cloth in his house for sale.
(continues on next page)

4583271/4575386/4585986.title: A Story
4583271/4575386/4585986.text:
One day a crowd of men were cutting hay in a field.  They had a can of milk in the field for a drink.  They broke up a weazel's nest.  After a while the weazel came and spat on the milk.  The men were afraid and they fixed the next and the weazel went back and spilled the milk for fear the men would drink it and get poisoned.



People were twelve years old before they wore shoes long ago.I never wore any shoes.  It is customary for children to go to school barefooted nowadays in summer.  nowadays customs
(continues on next page)

4583357/4582761/4586297.title: Déardaoin Dearg
4583357/4582761/4586297.text:
Bhí bean ann fadó agus bhí ceathar inghin aici. Lá amháin chuaidh an bhean chuig a' bhfigheadóir a' deilbh. Nuair a bhí an t-éadach réidh rinne an inghin is sine cóta di féin. Ní raibh an cóta i bhfad aici nuair a cailleadh í. Chuir an dara inghin an cóta uirthi féin agus ní raibh sé 'bhfad aice sin ach oiread nuair a cailleadh í. Chuir an treas inghin an cóta uirthi féin agus thárla an rud céadna di. Bhí an mháthair agus an inghin eile go brónach i na ndiaidh. Bhí an inghin seo ag a' sruthán (srán) lá a' nigheachán an chóta. Chonnaic sí cailleach ag déanamh uirthi. "Caith uait a' cóta sin," adeir a' chailleach, "mar is Diardaoin Dearg a deilbheadh an cóta sin agus duine ar bith a chuireas éadach air féin a deilbheadh an lá sin ní (i) bhfad é a shaoghal agus ní bheidh an t-éadach caithte go deó."



Bhí madarallta san áit seo fadó agus bhí sé an-chríonna. Bhí sé ráidhte dá gcasadh sé do dhuine agus é 'spáint sgian cois bhán dó nach mbacfadh sé leis.  Aon lá amháin bhí fear [?] ag dul go Magh Cuilin agus chas sé leis. 'Spáin a' fear sgian do a raibh cois bhán innti, agus d'imthigh an madarallta leis ansin. Is gear [?] gur chas fear eile do'n fhear seo agus d'fhiafruigh sé dó a' raibh aon sgian cois bhán aige, agus dubht. sé go raibh. Thug a' fear dó ansin an sgian a bhí aige féin, agus bhí sé féin annsin gan aon sgian. Is gear[?] gur chas a' madarallta leis a' bfear a fu[?] a' sgian. Nr. a chas d'aithin an madarallta an sgian. Rith sé leis ar an bpoinnte. Tháinic sé suas leis an gcéad fhear agus mharbhuigh sé é.

4583357/4582761/4586299.title: Déardaoin Dearg
4583357/4582761/4586299.text:
Bhí bean ann fadó agus bhí ceathar inghin aici. Lá amháin chuaidh an bhean chuig a' bhfigheadóir a' deilbh. Nuair a bhí an t-éadach réidh rinne an inghin is sine cóta di féin. Ní raibh an cóta i bhfad aici nuair a cailleadh í. Chuir an dara inghin an cóta uirthi féin agus ní raibh sé 'bhfad aice sin ach oiread nuair a cailleadh í. Chuir an treas inghin an cóta uirthi féin agus thárla an rud céadna di. Bhí an mháthair agus an inghin eile go brónach i na ndiaidh. Bhí an inghin seo ag a' sruthán (srán) lá a' nigheachán an chóta. Chonnaic sí cailleach ag déanamh uirthi. "Caith uait a' cóta sin," adeir a' chailleach, "mar is Diardaoin Dearg a deilbheadh an cóta sin agus duine ar bith a chuireas éadach air féin a deilbheadh an lá sin ní (i) bhfad é a shaoghal agus ní bheidh an t-éadach caithte go deó."



Bhí madarallta san áit seo fadó agus bhí sé an-chríonna. Bhí sé ráidhte dá gcasadh sé do dhuine agus é 'spáint sgian cois bhán dó nach mbacfadh sé leis.  Aon lá amháin bhí fear [?] ag dul go Magh Cuilin agus chas sé leis. 'Spáin a' fear sgian do a raibh cois bhán innti, agus d'imthigh an madarallta leis ansin. Is gear [?] gur chas fear eile do'n fhear seo agus d'fhiafruigh sé dó a' raibh aon sgian cois bhán aige, agus dubht. sé go raibh. Thug a' fear dó ansin an sgian a bhí aige féin, agus bhí sé féin annsin gan aon sgian. Is gear[?] gur chas a' madarallta leis a' bfear a fu[?] a' sgian. Nr. a chas d'aithin an madarallta an sgian. Rith sé leis ar an bpoinnte. Tháinic sé suas leis an gcéad fhear agus mharbhuigh sé é.

4583357/4582774/4586312.title: An Íocfadh sin thú?
4583357/4582774/4586312.text:
(continued from previous page)
duine aca, "bhfhéidir nach bhfuil tú dhá iompughadh ceart,"  d'iompuigh sé amach é agus bhuail sé ar an mbord é, acht ní raibh aon maith dhó ann. Chuir an t-óstóir fios ar na Gárdaí agus chaitheadh isteach i bpríosún iad.               Liam Ó Fatharta d'aithsgríobh



Tá cloich ar an mbaile seo -      againn-ne agus 'sé an t-ainm a tugtar uirthi "Cloch na h-Easóige."  Bhíodh neadracha déanta fúithe ag easógaí. Bhí fear 'na chomhnaidhe ar an mbaile san am chéadna ar a dtugaidís Micil Mór. Bhí faitchíos a chroidhe ar an bhfear seo go síolróchaidís agus nach bhfágfaidís cearc ná lacha ar an mbaile. Chuaidh sé suas tráthnóna amháin nó gur chuir sé ceann amháin amach ó'n gcloich agus mharbhuigh sé í. D'imthigh sé abhaile annsin ach lean ceann de na sean-easógaí anuas é.   Chuaidh sí isteach sa teach go dtí é agus shíl sí é mharbhughadh ach bhí mada maith aige agus thiomáin sé amach í. San oidhche lá'r na bháireach tháinic an easóg arís agus níor fhág sí ceann de'n ál éanacha géabha a bhí sa teach nár mharbhuigh sí.

4583271/4575391/4586388.title: Wild Animals
4583271/4575391/4586388.text:
Wild AnimalsThe wild animals are the fox rabbet, wesel, rat, mouse, and the hair. The fox lives in borrows in the wood. The rat and wesel lives in burrows in a ditch or in a corn stack. The hair lives in furs or in long grass. The mouse lives in a corn stack. The food the fox eats are hens and lambs. The rat and the mouse lives in oats. The rabbet and the hair lives on grass sand and water. The wesel lives on rats and mice. No one of the wild animals does and good but the wesel. They foxes tongue is a cure for taking out a thorn.



A StoryThere was once a man and the fox used to come to the hen house and kill the hens. One night he set traps around the hen house to catch the fox. The fox came and he saw the traps. He got a clod of turf and closed the traps. Then he went in and killed the hens. Pat Maguire.

4583289/4576768/4586406.title: Signs of the Weather as Observed in the Sky, Sun, Moon, Stars, Clouds and Rainbow
4583289/4576768/4586406.text:
1) When the sky looks red at night it is the sign of a storm.When the hills seem to be near you, it is the sign of wet weather, and when far away, fine weather. 2) When dust on road-way rises with the wind is the sign of wet weather. 3) If insects are seen creeping on the road, it fortells rain.When smoke goes up straight from chimney, if sut falls down from it, or if a blue lights is seen in the fire, rain is expected.



1) The only person I heard of that could catch hares and rabbits by running after is John Carty of Toomard.2) The best walker I heard of is Patrick Mannion who often walked to Dublin in two days. 3) Thomas Noone about two and a half miles north of this school who could mow about 7 rds in one day was the best mower in this district. There was often

4566060/4563550/4586773.title: An Chaoi a Rinneadh Páideogaí Fadó

4569070/4568953/4586861.title: Wild Animals
4569070/4568953/4586861.text:
There are not many wild animals in this district. The most common ones are deer, fox, hedgehog, water dog, hare rabbit rats ferrits and weasel. The badger the (hare) rabbit rats and the hedgehog lives in burrows. The hare lives in rushes or long grass. The hare is a very timed animal it is very easy to waken him. There was once a man and he caught a hare. He skinned him and cured the skin and put it on the back of a vest. One day he was digging potatoes he took off his vest and left it on the ground. He had a dog with him. The dog lay near the vest. It was not long until the vest ran off and the dog after it and caught it and brought it back to him.There was a deer once in Castlegrove. He went from that to Knockma. What he used to feed on was grass, turnips and hay. The weasel is a very dangerous animal. There was once a man mowing hay. He had a drink with him in a jug there
(continues on next page)

4569070/4568984/4586939.title: Fairs
4569070/4568984/4586939.text:
(continued from previous page)
pigs and they buyer for cattle and sheep  The old people say it is not lucky for the owner to give the bridle with a horse



Long ago there used to be a lot of Wild Animals in Ireland but nowadays they are not so plentiful  The most common - wild animals around this district are the Deer, fox, ferret, waterdog, hare. rabbit. Hedgehog and weasel.  The Deer is not very plentiful in this district.  There was a deer rambling through Castle-grove wood not very long ago and it went away from that to Knock-ma.  The fox is
(continues on next page)

4583299/4577604/4586974.title: Strange Animals
4583299/4577604/4586974.text:
In this district there is not much very strange about animals. I often heard that if a badger caught you by the leg he would not let you go until a bone would smash. It is also said that a black pig was seen in the village of Crossford. When people used be coming home from a place late at night they would see the black pig.One time a foal came up out of a lake near Loughrea and a man caught him. He used to have the foal racing and he used win every race. One day there were races near a lake and the foal was racing. The foal was winning the race and there was only one round to go when the foal and the jock ran
(continues on next page)

4583290/4576838/4587079.title: Comharthaí agus Nósanna a Chleachtaítear san gCeapaigh

4583307/4578353/4587720.title: The Kingfisher Visits the Gort River
4583307/4578353/4587720.text: A remarkable river flows through Gort. It rises in the Derrybrian mountains, and goes under the ground seven times, before it reaches the sea in Kinvara Bay. My father spends all his leisure hours fishing, and he knows the strange birds, that visit marshy places.The King-Fisher is a bird seen sometimes on the Gort river, He is not much larger than a swallow. He has small legs, and a long bill. The upper clap of the bill is black, and the lower yellow. This bird has many colours. The crown of its head and its wings are of a blackish green, spotted with azure. The under and side of its body is orange colour. Its tail is short, and is of a rich deep blue. Its feet are yellow. This bird lives on fish. He builds his nest on the river bank. The female lays from five to nine eggs. If these are robbed she won't mind, she will come back again and lay there.
4583307/4578353/4587720.school_info: School: Clochar na Trócaire, Gort Inse Guaire

4583308/4578391/4587811.title: The Man and the Hare
4583308/4578391/4587811.text: Once upon a time a man was cutting turf. He kept cutting on down straight into the bog hole, and when he thought he had enough cut he could not come up because the hole was very deep. A hare was passing at the time, and the man caught his tail trying to come up. The hare pulled on his best trying to pull the man up but the man was too heavy and the tail broke. From that day till this every hare has a short tail. Then the man caught the hares two hind legs and the hare pulled him out of the hole. With such pulling the hares hind legs became longer then the two front ones and from that day till this every hare's hind legs are longer than the front ones.

4583325/4579956/4588212.title: A Blessed Well
4583325/4579956/4588212.text:
(continued from previous page)
the shape of the bishops cap if you wash your warts in it will banish them.



Long ago there was a lot of wild animals in  Walyston wood but now they are all dead. The only wild animals that are in it now are deers, badgers, foxes, rabbits, horses and squirrels. The cures for these wild animals are: A foxes tongue is the best you could get to take out a thorn. A deers tallow is good to cure rheumatism, if you melt it and rub it on your sides.



Unlucky marriages; It is unlucky for two brothers or two sisters to get married in the same year. Pisrogues; The people throw old shoes after the two that are getting married. Get married on Monday for health, Tuesday for wealth,
(continues on next page)

4583273/4575564/4591348.title: Wild Animals
4583273/4575564/4591348.text:
The animals in this district are the rat, rabbit, hare, fox and badger. The hares and rabbits do but little harm.  The rat is one of the most harmful animals in this district at present. The fox and badger are hated by the people. They kill fowl, and lambsThe tongue of the fox is used for taking out thorns. The meat of the hedge hog when boiled and made into soup is given as a cure to a person who has the whooping cough, or the yellow jaundice.



In the village of Brooklawn there is a field called "lios na craobha" it was called that name because in the olden times threes grew round the lios. The village of Lehid is about six miles from Tuam, there is a field called gleann dubh. It was called that name because the four fences were very high and bushes grew on the top of the ditches so that the field was very dark.
(continues on next page)

4583293/4577100/4591495.title: Local Wild Birds
4583293/4577100/4591495.text: There are a lot of wild birds around here, namely the Cuckoo, Blackbird, Robin, Swallow, Mackpie, Corncrak and Thrush. The Robin got his red breast when Our Lord was dying on the cross he was trying to take the crown of thorns off Our Lord's head, and a drop of blood fell on the Robin's breast. That is why he is called Robin Redbreast. Most of the birds go away to other countrys except the little Robins.The Swallow builds his nest in a shed. The Cuckoo makes no nest of his own. He lays his eggs in other birds nests. Then the eggs are hatched, and the young cuckoo comes out, and hunts the rest of the birds from the nest.

4583347/4581678/4593183.title: The Swallow
4583347/4581678/4593183.text: The SwallowThe swallow migrates to foreign countries about the middle of October.  Before they go they gather together in large flocks on the tops of houses or on wires.  When they are going each brings a piece of stick in it's mouth which to rest on when they are crossing the ocean. Some of them rest on the masts of ships while crossing.  They only build one nest and that will do them for years.  They build no nest on the following years they come here as they come to the same nests every year, but they repair the old ones with moss and clay.  They never come near the houses looking for food.  When the swallows are up high you can be sure the flies are up high.  If they are up high it is the sign of good weather.  When the seagulls come inland from the sea-shore it is the sign of bad weather.  When the crows are odd in their flight or when they dive upwards or downwards.Got from My Uncle Bill age 48 years, Ballykerin, Bullaun, Loughrea.By Pauline Keane, same address on 1-12-38.

4591086/4589232/4593307.title: A Story
4591086/4589232/4593307.text:
(continued from previous page)
ditch. The cripple was. It was a woman that was in it and she pretended she was a cripple. But that days out she had to walk.



A lion chanced to be resting in a field one day. An ass brayed very loudly and frightened the lion. The lion ran away and the ass went after him. There was much chasing in the field. At last the lion turned back to see the big animal that was after him. The lion turned back and tore the ass to pieces. That the ass throught was his bravery was only his ruin.

4591086/4589233/4593312.title: A Story
4591086/4589233/4593312.text: During a great war, two horses were used in drawing a battery of artillery. These two horses were companions. During the war one of the horses was killed by a shell. Afterwards the surviving horse was tied up in the usual way. His food was brought to him but he refused to eat.Other horses were brought round him to cheer him, but it was no good. The horse died shortly afterwards and was buried by the soldiers near his old friend.

4591086/4589234/4593314.title: A Story
4591086/4589234/4593314.text:
A lion once caught a mouse and he was hungry. The lion said that he would eat him. The mouse said that if he would let him go he might free the lion again. The lion let the mouse go on that condition. Another time the lion got caught in a net. The mouse saw the lion in the net. The mouse had pity for the lion when the he saw the lion. So the mouse began to cut the net as well as he could until the mouse freed the lion.



A cat one day caught a mouse. The mouse said, "All decent people wash their hands and face before they eat. You only wash your face after you eat." The cat was near a stone-wall. The cat began to wash his face and paws before he would eat the mouse. When the mouse saw the cat washing his face he ran into the stone-wall from the cat. That is the reason why
(continues on next page)

4591086/4589234/4593317.text:

The lion let the mouse go on that condition. Another time the lion got caught in a net. The mouse saw the lion in the net. The mouse had pity for the lion when the he saw the lion. So the mouse began to cut the net as well as he could until the mouse freed the lion.

4591086/4589296/4593495.title: Bia na Seanaimsire
4591086/4589296/4593495.text:
(continued from previous page)
The people used to make potato-bread and oaten bread, and boxty bread to eat. The used to make farles of the bread and bake it in a pan. The people used not eat much meat long ago, but when they used to eat it, it is salty meat they used to have. Some times they used to have fish for their dinner. They used to buy the fish in the market. It is milk they used to drink instead of tea.



A man was walking one day through a large city. At a street corner he saw a boy with a number of small birds for sale in a cage. He looked with sadness upon the little birds flying about the cage, peeping through the wires and try-
(continues on next page)

4583349/4581906/4606132.title: The Wild Animals in this Place
4583349/4581906/4606132.text:
The Wild Animals in this place.The principal wild animals in this place are the hare, the rabbit, the weasel and the badger.The fox is a small brown, red animal with a coat of red fur. He steals hens, geese, ducks and turkeys from the farmer.He makes a burrow in the ground but he spends most of his time in the wood or in a lonely place. The hare and the rabbit are almost alike. They live in burrows in the ground. Many people enjoy hunting after them with hounds.The badger is an animal with a coat of hair almost as big as the fox. He is not a big rogue like the fox. Sometimes he comes out of his den, he goes into a field where there are potatoes and turnips and he eats some of them.It is said that if a person killed a weasel and made a purse of his skin they would never be
(continues on next page)

4583351/4582112/4606320.title: (no title)
4583351/4582112/4606320.text:
There is an old fort in Coxtown which can be seen yet.  There are many big banks of clay around it.  In the middle there is a big hole going into the ground.It is said that it was made by the Irish when Cromwell was in Ireland so that when they saw Cromwell's soldiers coming they could hide in it.The people believe that if you could get into the end of it you would find old guns and swords. If you stood on the top of the fort you could see another one about a mile distant.



One day John Linnane of Coxtown went out shooting. He had not gone far when he saw two weasels and he thought that they were two rabbits. He fired two shots at them and killed one. When he went to the dead weasel the other one did not run away. John brought home the dead weasel but the other weasel followed him. He fired another shot at the weasel but did not succeed in killing it.That night when John was going to bed he forgot to close the window. In the middle of the night the weasel came into the room through the window. He jumped up on the bed and caught John by the neck. But John awakened and killed the weasel.
(continues on next page)

4583351/4582124/4606338.title: A Story
4583351/4582124/4606338.text: A Story         Mrs. Hallinan, Ballycahalan, Gort.One night a fox went in through the roof of a thatched cabin belonging to Martin Kearns and killed all the hens he had.  When he had the damage done he tried to escape but failed.  When Martin got up next morning he went out to let out the hens and he saw the fox lying on the ground.  He thought he was dead so he threw him out.  The fox got up and ran off as well as ever.  If a badger got a grip of your leg he would not let go until he would hear a bone cracking.  If a woman who was going on a journey met a hare on the path it would not be lucky if she didn't turn.  If a person was bringing a hare into the house he should split his ear first.  The milk that a ferret would leave after him is a very good cure for all sorts of colds.  It is said that if a weasel spat on you you would be blood-poisoned.  If you tried to kill a rat when fighting with a weasel and the rat to bite you the weasel would cure it by licking it. Warts: If you rubbed a black snail to your warts they would all go or if you killed a snail between two stones and left him there for eight days without looking at him the warts would be gone before the ninth day.  If you buried a straw in the clay the warts would be gone before the straw was rotten.

4583275/4575842/4606391.title: Ainmhithe Allta
4583275/4575842/4606391.text:
These are the wild animals that are to be seen in our place: the rabbit; the hare; the gráinneóg or hedgehog as it is called in some places; the weasel; the fox; the squirrel and occasionally a badger is seen in the woods and sometimes a waterdog is seen in the rivers. Sometimes also a wild ferret is seen among the fields.The Rabbit. The rabbit is the most common of our wild animals. Rabbits inhabit places where there are a lot of furze and are also plentiful in woods. They live in holes called burrows bored through ditches. Rabbits are a nuisance to farmers. They eat a lot of grass and sometimes completely destroy a field of cabbage; turnips; beet and young oats in a few nights. They are particularly fond of cabbage.The farmer destroys them by shooting; snaring and trapping them. A snare is made by first getting a roll of snare-wire and a piece of a board two feet long. At each end of this board a nail is put. The roll of wire is then opened and the end of it tied on to one nail and the rest of it twisted round both nails six times. The wire is then taken out and where it was twisted round the second nail there will be a little hole or eye. A round piece of a stick is now got and put into this eye and a rope is put on the other end of the snare and a peg is tied on to it. Sixpence worth of snare-wire and five yards of rope
(continues on next page)

4602696/4595754/4606520.title: An Fáth a bhFuil Olann ar an gCaora agus Fionnadh ar Ghabhar
4602696/4595754/4606520.text: Lá amháin bhí saighdiúirí ag toruigheacht Íosa is bhíodar ag teacht suas leis, is ní raibh aon áit le dul aige ach isteach i mbolg gabhair a bhí ar an sliabh.Nuair a d'airigh an gabhar É thosuigh sí ag méidhleach is ag imtheacht fíadháin.Bhí fhios ag na saighdiúirí gur i mbolg an ghabhair bhí Íosa is lean siad an gabhar is sheas an gabhar gur rug siad uirthi. D'imthigh Íosa i ngan fhios do na saighdiúirí is chuaigh sé i mbolg na caorach. Luighe an chaora síos is thosaigh sí ag cangailt a círe is ní raibh fhios ag na saighdiúirí cé raibh Íosa is caitheadh ar an tóir tabhairt suas.Bhíodh olann deas bhog ar an ngabhar an t-am sin is bhí fionnadh fada fíadháin ar an gcaora, ach d'athruigh Íosa é an t-am seo is chuir sé olann ar an gcaora is fionnadh ar an ngabhar is is mar sin atáid go dtí an lá indiú.

4591089/4589601/4606680.title: Old Cures
4591089/4589601/4606680.text:
(continued from previous page)
Old Cures cont.wrist a strap will stop this at once.  If you sprain your ankle an old cure for it is to put it the mill race.Teller Mrs. W. Dowdsame addressWriter: J DowdFlaskaghDunmoreCo. Galway



Wild Animals 8/9/38There was once a fox in Cappa, Dunmore, Co. Galway who used to bring all kind of fowl from the village.  Everyone knew him because he used to trick the people and he had no tail.  He was very cute and cunning.  None of the people could ever catch him in a trap or shoot him.  One day however when he was very old he got
(continues on next page)

4591089/4589603/4606681.title: Wild Animals
4591089/4589603/4606681.text:
(continued from previous page)
around the corner of the barn on three legs, the other leg was broken in the trap.  Some weeks later the dead fox was found in a ridge of potatoes and half a goose near him.  The people also dug out his den and it was filled with old bones.Bertie ColemanCappaDunmoreCo Galway

4591089/4589604/4606683.title: Folklore - Wild Animals
4591089/4589604/4606683.text: Folklore 12-9-'38Wild AnimalsThe weasel is a small animal who kills rabbits and hens.  People say that long ago when the Danes came to Ireland they brought the weasel is called the Danes cat.  The weasel kills rabbits but he does not eat them he only sucks their blood.Writer:  Mary RafteryClougherBallinloughCo RoscommonTeller: Mr RafteryClougherBallinloughCo Roscommon

4606492/4593817/4606780.title: Áitainmneacha
4606492/4593817/4606780.text:
(continued from previous page)
míle siar ó thuaidh de'n bhean bháidhte tá áit ann ar a dtugtar Maoidhm an t-sagairt. Bhí sagart ag dul siar ann fadó i mbád agus d'iompuigheadh an bád agus bádhadh an sagart. Tá an t-ainm sin air fós. Tuairim is míle siar uaidh ta áit ar a dtugtar Meádh Pheadair na Cruite. Na céadta bliadhain ó shoin, bhí Peadar ag iascach ann mar gheall ar chruit a bheith air. Tá an t-ainm sin air ó shoin.



Ainmhidhthe AlltaDeirtí go mbíodh sionnaigh fiadháin in-Árainn fadó. Sé an t-ainm a tugtar ar an bpoll a mbíonn siad 'na gcodladh ann brocais. Itheann na sionnaigh éin, lachain, cearca agus éanachaí na spéire. Déaneann siad an-díoghbháil. Marbhuigheann siad uain agus éin ar na daoiníbh. An bainne a fhághann an firéad ina dhiaidh tá leigheas ann ar Bhruitíneach. Bhíodh girrfhiadh in-Árainn fadó. Dheinidís nead insna tumachaibh agus insna coilltíbh. Ní mórán
(continues on next page)

4606492/4593819/4606786.title: Ainmhithe Allta
4606492/4593819/4606786.text:
Seo cuid de'n sna ainmhidhthibh fíadhána atá le fághail in Árainn An coinín, an luch, an t-all chuach an easóg. 'Sé an chaoch a bdéanann an coinín a nead thíos i bpoll ina mbíonn calamh bog agus nuair a bhíonns coiníní óga aice dúnann sí an poll nuair a imthigheann sí uatha ag fághail bídh dóibh. Is cuma leis an luich cá ndéanann sí a nead, acht an áit is feileamhnaighe di. Is faoi n leacrachaibh agus na clocha a bhíonns nead ag an tall chuach. Is a n-iomairce fataí a dhéanann an easóg a nead de ghnáth. Is féar glas a itheann an coinín agus itheann an luch arán agus marbhuigheann sí coiníní freisin. 'Sé an chaoi a mbíonn an easóg ag marbhadh coiníní, luch agus éan, agus dhá n-ithe. Itheann na daoine coiníní agus marbhuigheann na h-easóga ortha iad. Déanann an franncach níos mó millteanais ná leas. Seo cleas do bhí ag an mada ruadh. Chuaidh fear lá amháin as Conn Mhaicne Mara go Gaillimh ar mhargadh. Nuair a tháinig sé abhaile bhí an mada ruadh istigh roimhe agus millteanas mór déanta aige. "Tá tú ingreim anois" arsa an fear leis, agus d'fhan sé ag an dorus ar fhaitchíos go ngabhadh an masa ruadh amach. Rug an mada ruadh ar phéire bróg agus chaith sé san teinidh iad ag ceapadh go ngabhadh an fear dhá sábháil agus go n-imtheochadh sé féin amach
(continues on next page)

4591089/4589656/4606814.title: Fox Rids himself of the Fleas
4591089/4589656/4606814.text:
(continued from previous page)
and rolled himself on it to dry himself.Writer: William KellyBeaughDunmoreCo GalwayTeller John GroganRoymonghanDunmoreCo Galway



One night a fox entered a hen cabin through a hole in the door. He killed and ate as much hens as he possibly could and when he tried to make his escape through the hole in the door he found he was too fat. He lay down on the floor of the cabin and he pretended he was dead. Next morning when the farmer went to let out his hens he saw the fox lying on the floor of the cabin and he thought he was dead. He
(continues on next page)

4591089/4589659/4606816.title: Folklore
4591089/4589659/4606816.text:
(continued from previous page)
the hare would run one of the hedgehogs was always before him.    continued on page (6)

Folklore 23rd November 1938The most thing that damage land is the rabbits, they ate the hay and oats.  They bore the ditches and dig holes on them and kick them down.  They tramp the good land.  There was once a man who used to catch the rabbits with traps and snares and he used to send them to Dunmore and used to sell them and he used to get four pence and five for each of them.



Folklore   24-11-'38The luckiest time of the year to get married is June.  The luckiest day of the week is Thursday.  It is right to wear  borrowed clothes when they are getting married.  Side cars and horses were used for driving home.  Old shoes were thrown after the couple for luck.
(continues on next page)

4606492/4593821/4606854.title: Ainmhithe Allta
4606492/4593821/4606854.text:
Ainmhidhthe Allta.San am fadó do tháinig  sionnach mór isteach i-n-deire báid as Conn Mhaicne Mara, agus ní raibh fhios ag aon duine dá raibh san m-bád é. Tuairim is céad bliadhan ó shoin do bhí sé ag déanamh scriosa móir ar uain agus ar chaoirighíbh i-n-Árainn, agus do chuir daoine clár lag ar bhruach aille na Lochán. Lá amháin sheas an sionnach air, agus thuit sé san bh-fairrge.Tháinig mada fiadháin isteach h-oileainaibh, agus is é an chaoi a shnámh sé anoir, agus bhí muinntir Árann scriosta aige mar bhí sé ag marbhughadh caorach ortha. Acht aon oidhche amháin chonnaic na daoine nead déanta aige istigh i-d-teach beag, agus an oidhche i-n-a dhiaidh rug siad air agus mharbhuigh siad é.Is le gairid a tháinig na h-easóga go hÁrainn. Níl mórán luch ná coinín fágtha i-n-Árainn. An chéad uair a tháinig na h-easóga go h-Árainn bhí roinnt scátha ag na daoiníbh rómpa acht níl an oiread scátha aca rómpa anois, agus atá faoi chat. Tá ainmhidhthe eile i-n-Árainn ar a d-tugtar allchuach. Creideann daoine má bhéarann siad ortha, agus a dteangacha a chuimilt ó-n-a-d-trioballaibh go dtí a g-cloigníbh go bh-fuil leigheas ag baint leis.
(continues on next page)

4602669/4594050/4614905.title: Bird-Lore
4602669/4594050/4614905.text:
Bird Lore.When the swallows fly low it is a sign of rain.  When the crows lie on the walls it is a sign of rain.



The Lore of certain days.Horses are not yoked on Whit Monday as it was supposed to be a day for accidents.  Millers don't work their mills on St Martin's Day.Any horse born on Whit Monday turns out to be a wicked one.

4602676/4594619/4615118.title: The Woman with the Pisreoga
4602676/4594619/4615118.text:
(continued from previous page)
of the cow's tail and didn't part from the cow until she went to her own house.



The old people say that if a person is going on a journey and if he or she meets one magpie on the road he should return home because he would have no luck for the rest of the time. Two for good luck but three for a marriage. Four for a boy. Five for to get silver. Six for to get gold. Seven for a story that can never be told.If a person is going on a journey and meets a red haired woman that person would have no luck either. If a man is going out fishing and meets a woman he would catch no fish it is said.

4602676/4594640/4615237.title: Treasure Hunters
4602676/4594640/4615237.text:
(continued from previous page)
long digging when they found a nest of frogs. Soon the hole they had dug was nearly full with frogs and after a while big frogs appeared, about the side of persons head and chased the men that were trying to get the money.



Long ago in Errismore their was a plague of rats. This man came to Errismore and he had a charm for putting away rats. They asked him to put away the plague of rats and he did. He wrote on a piece of paper some words and put it at the mouth of the rats-hole. The next day the plague of rats was gone. A man saw the rats and the leader with a piece of paper in his mouth.

4602677/4594731/4615297.title: The Weasel's Revenge
4602677/4594731/4615297.text: One day as young boys were herding cows they saw a weasel running along a  wall.  The dog followed him and killed him.  The boys caught him and threw him into another field.  about an hour after when the boys were eating their supper they saw a weasel at the window and he began tapping at it.  The boys would not go out but they put out the dog thinking he would kill him but it was the weasel that killed the dog and he ran away then.

4613677/4607627/4616849.title: Wild Animals
4613677/4607627/4616849.text: 1. The wild animals that live near us are, rabbits, hares weasels, rats, mice and otters2. The rabbit lives in a burrow and in holes in ditches.3. The hares live in nests in long grass4. The weasels live in holes in ditches5. The rats live sometimes in pig houses watching the pigs food.6. The mice live in holes in the ground and in pits of potatoes7. The otters live on banks of rivers, and they are very fierce8. The fox went one morning to a wood in search of food. He saw a crow which had a piece of meat in her mouth. He started praising her and she began to "crow" and the meat  fell to the ground. He took it and ran off

4613677/4607628/4616851.title: Story
4613677/4607628/4616851.text: Once there was a man and there were a lot of foxes around his place. They attacked everybodies hens expect his own. One day the huntsmen set out to catch them. The chased one big one in particular. They were after him until her ran into the man house. They wanted to go in after him, but the man would not let them. He save the foxes life and the next morning he let him out. Every morning afterwards there would be a big fat goose at his door, because he saved the foxes life.

4613677/4607629/4616853.title: Story
4613677/4607629/4616853.text: There was another man and there were alot of foxes around his place. He set a trap for one who was always coming into his yard. The fox was caught in the trap and when he saw the man coming in the morning he laid down and pretended to be dead. The man came to the fox and threw him over his shoulder. He thought he was dead. When he reached the garden gate he threw down the fox to open the gate, and he ran away.

4613677/4607630/4616854.title: Stories
4613677/4607630/4616854.text: 1. There was a man once coming home from a fair, and he had thirty pounds in his pocket tied up in a handkerchief. He caught a hare and he tied the hares foot with the handkerchief. He put him into his pocket. The man put his hand to his pocket for his pipe, and the hare ran away with the handkerchief which contained the thirty pounds.2. Once upon a time there was a hound following a hare and he wounded him. The hare ran into an old house. The house and huntsmen followed him in. When they went in, all they found was an old women on the floor.

agus bhí ochair ag na buachaillí freisin i ngan fhios don athair. Gach oidhche san seachtmhain biodh damhsa i dteach áirighthe agus théigfeadh na buachaillí ann tar éis a naoí a chlog nó mar sin, mar sean fhear dobhead Seán agus theighfeadh sé ar a codhladh go moch agus rachfad na buachaillí ar a gcodhladh freisin le h- aghaidh leath uair nó mar sin agus deirighidís aríst í ngan fhios don athair agus theighfead siad go dtí an damhsa. Dfanfad siad ag an damhsa go dtí cúig no sé a clog ar maidin agus bí bheadh fhios ag an tathair é cor ar bith mar gheall ar na h-ochair. Bhí cead acú dul amach isteach uair ba mhaith leo.



Bhí an sionnach maidin amhain go moch agus é ag cluanaidheacht thart ar cró na gcearc. Bhí sé ag smurtacht roimhe go cúramach ar fhaitchíos go ndéanfadh sé a mhídh thapaidh. Thógfadh sé na cosa go rúd agus leigeadh sé anuas iad go h-éadtrom . Ach da airighe agus ba áirdeallaighe dá raibh sé beag an mhaith dó é. Níor airighe sé ariamh gur cuir sé a chos a bhí le h-ais an cró. Ní túisge a chuir dá dfaisg an

The woman took the man to court and was winning the case when Dan OConnel the man's lawyer stood up and put his hand into his pocket and took up a fist of oats.  He put it into his hat and began to shake it around in the courthouse.  Then the judge  said "Do you expect that to grow"? and Dan answered "It has as much chance to grow as chickens have to come out of the eggs she gave the man before he went to USA."



Bhí buachaill beag ann fadó agus buachaill crosta do b'eadh é. Bhí se an-saidhbhir agus bhí a lán mbréagán aige, acht dá dheire d'éirigh se tuirse bheith ag súgrádh le na mbréagán agus dubhairt sé leis féin go mba maith leis nach bheith sé in a bhuachaill agus tuige go rugadh é agus é fear. Taréis tamaill tháinig fear beag suas leis agus dfíafruigh sé de cé'n fáth a dubhairt sé sin, ní freagra an buachaill agus dúirt an fearín leis "An maith leat bheith í méaróg Nodlag agus thosuigh an buachaillín ag gol, annsin dubhairt sé leis cé'n sórt rud a mhaith leis agus dubhairt se annsin ba mhaith liom bheith im buachaill.

4613671/4606950/4623736.text:

him and tripped him over. Then he caught a hold of him by the horns and put him into a barn.  When the hunters came the tinker said that he caught the deer and my grandfather said that it was himself caught him and he got the 10/ - Then they bought a half barrel of porter with the shilling.  Tinker Ward had a lot of saucepans and the saucepans were rattling all over the house and they were all drinking saucepans of porter.  In November 1879 they caught the deer.



When soot falls we are to have rain.  When the blaze on the fire is blue we are to have rain.  When there is a wing around the morning we are to have rain.  When the wind is from the North was will have frost or snow.  When the sun goes down in a cloud we will have  rain.  When they frog is yellow we will have good weather and when he is black we will have rain.  When the smoke goes straight out of the chimney we are to have rain.  When crickets sing we will have rain.  When the duck quacks we are to have rain.  When the spider from his cobweb creeps we are to have rain.  When the sun is pale when it is setting we are to have rain.



If anything died in a person he would say, "céad fáilte ar a ghrásta dia"

4613671/4606952/4623742.title: A Nest of Swans
4613671/4606952/4623742.text:
A nest of swans was up in Lough Lorigeen one time, and a bit over from the lake there was an old shed.  This day a man went looking for the nest and found it.  There were no swans in the nest at the time and he went to pull out the nest when all at once he saw a swan swimming towards him.  He threw the nest there and made for home but just then he heard the swan screech and she over his head.  She was coming down very low over the man.  The man ran towards the shed and the swan followed him all the way but he landed as far as the shed before the swan caught up to him and he shut the door.



There was a cow seen above in Lough Lorigeen and she was like any other cow.  She had no horns.  A man was walking along the lake but as soon as the cow saw him she jumped down under the water and was never seen again.



I was sixteen or seventeen years when Patsy brought me shoes from England and when I wore them I would

(continued from previous page)
he met an ass and he thought it was a ghost. He gave the ass a blow and went home Glenamaddy way instead. When halfway home he heard something screetching, and going across the road. He met the funeral of the men killed in Domammon at one oclock. When he come home to his own house he knocked at the door and he was let in. There was not a spark in the fire that he didnt think was up in top of the roof of the house. His father asked him did he see a funeral and he said he did. As soon as the father mentioned the word funeral the fire settled down.



If there is a plague of rats in the house and you want to change them to some-other place get an Owls quill and dip it in the blood of a raven and say some word like "rats be gone" or something of the like and immediately the rats will have disappeared to whatever place you wish. Paddy Tiernan Leahive had a charm to change rats.

not lucky to hunt crows. It's a sign of bad luck if crows change their nests from place to another. Crows start to build on 1st March, but should 1st fall on a Sunday a kipin they will not carry. That's a lesson for us -- a warning to man.



"A singing cricket never sang in a house where a person is dying".  On one occasion a priest was saying "Oh o he or he will die tonight' the priest quoted the above Sayings of the Gáurlach Clannach



"Is mairig a bheith ins a dtír gan a bheith tréan""Is mairig a mbíonn charad fánnIs mairig a mbíonn a chlann gan rathIs mairig dhéanfheas branar de'n t-síol (fallow land)Is rí-mhairig dabra(ns) comhrádh gan suimThis applies to old bachelors    who remain unmarried - unwise is the man that seeds fallow land.Said by one of the cleverest men that ever lived  -  I heard it from my mother. R.I.P.



(1) The man that will get me, wont keep me, wont have me when he wants me.

(1) Mí adh mór, (2) Giorrach an saoghal agus (3) damnu siorruide.(misfortune is shortness of life and damination)



A tailor was going to have a joke at the expense of the pedlar and he said:-Nach é Donachadh atá caoiAgus gan aon bhrígh i do bhástaI roball mná na tíre le na cuid sháwltaD, mar stopaidh tú ag fórt GanlaighDéanfaidh mise rann díotA rachais as seo go bheinn eada'S go millfaidh an meid eadaigh atá in siopa Tullacaoch.

4613703/4610391/4625343.title: Ainmhithe Allta
4613703/4610391/4625343.text:
Tá cuid mhaith d'ainmhidhthe allta sa tír seo fós. Siad na h-ainmhidhthe allta is coitchiannta an sionnach an easóg, an broc, an luch, an dobhar-chú, an coinín, an girrfiadh, an mada crainn, agus an ghrainneóg.Sé an sionnach an ceann is fearr a bhfuil eolas againn air. Tá go leor sgéalta innsighthe faoí clisteacht an t-sionnaigh. Bíonn pluais an t-sionnaigh i lar na coille. Bíonn go leor cnámha agus cleitumhachaí taobh amuigh de'n phluais aige. Athruigheann an mathair na cuileán ogo o áit go h-áit ar fhaitchíos go ngeobhfaidhe amach  iad. Marbhuigheann an sionneach cearca, lachain, agus géabha. Nuair a bhíos an sionnach ag teacht in-aice lé teach, tosuigheann sé ag tafann ar eagla go mbeadh aon mada ann Deirtear go bfuil leigheas  i dteanga an t-sionnaigh. Ma cuirtear teanga an t-sionnaigh lé dealg nac
(continues on next page)

4613694/4609439/4625367.title: Ainmhithe Allta
4613694/4609439/4625367.text:
Seo iad ainmneacha na n-ainmhidhthe atá ar fághail fiadháin annseo - (1) an broc, (2) an mad ruadh, (3) an girrfiadh (4) coinín (5) gráinneog agus an easóg.An Broc - fá chloich mhóir a bhíos cómhnuidhe ar an ainmhidhe seo. Bíonn a theach déanta as féar, caonach agus fionnadh. Nuair a bhíos clann óg aice bíonn sí ana faochmhar ar fad. Má fheiceann sí duine ag teacht ritheann sé fán a dhéin agus briseann sé cnámha a chos agus annsin briseann sí cnámh an sgórnaigh agus annsin imthigheann léithe. Itheann sé eascoin san Samhradh.An Mada Ruadh:- Níl dul ó chríonnacht an mhada ruadh, deirtear, mar innsigheann cuid de na sgéalta dúinn. Déanann sé cuid mhaith dioghbhála ámh, mar goideann sé géanna, lacain, cearca agus sicíní. Is fuath le mnaoí an tighe é agus dá bhfághadh sí seans  mharbhóchadh sí é.
(continues on next page)

4602689/4595337/4626020.title: A Story
4602689/4595337/4626020.text: Once upon a time there lived a man in an old tatched house. One evening as the man was coming home after milking the cows he saw a weasel crossing the road and he killed him with a stone.In the middle of the night a weasel came and killed him.One day a man was hunting in Glás na Coigly and one of the dogs ran after a hare and he broke his leg so the man ran home for his gun.When he came again to the hare under a cliff and fired a shot at him. At that moment the hare became a witch and the man fell off in a weakness and when he got alright the witch was gone.I heard this story from my father who lives in Rockfield

4602691/4595399/4626132.title: Díoltas na hEasóige
4602691/4595399/4626132.text: Dioghaltas na h-Easóige.    Lá breágh gréinne i mí lúghnasa bhí fear ag baint fhéir i pairc mór agus nuair bhí sé 'ghá mbaint cheap sé go raibh rud cruaidh sáidhte ins an speil agus d'fhéach sé suas agus céard bhí ann ach easóg óg agus í marbh. Nior cheap an fear go raibh aon dochar ann agus chuaidh sé abhaile go sásta.    Bhí sé de ghnáth ag an bhfear sin bheith ag caitheamh tobac san oidhche. An oidhche sin chuala sé torann ag an doras ach cheap sé nach raibh ann act an madadh agus níor oscail sé an doras. Act tar éis tamaill chuala sé an torann airís, agus annsin chuaidh sé go dtí an doras agus d'oscail sé é. Fe mar a cheap se ní raibh ann act an madadh. ach d'fhuaraigh a chuid fola in a chuisleachaibh nuair a chonnaic sé an rud a bhí ag an madadh--mar bhí greim fiacla ag an sean-easóg air.   Annsin chreid sé go raibh an sean-easóg ag teacht ar ais cun sásamh  a bhaint amach mar gheall ar an easóg a mharbhú sé.

4583343/4581464/4626165.title: Buying and Selling
4583343/4581464/4626165.text:
Shops  were common in the olden times the same as now. People had not far to go to the shops at that time, because there were shops all through the country. Buying and selling was carried on after Mass in the olden time and it is still pratised. The articles sold in this way were tea, sugar, loaves, tobacco and matches. Money was not given always for goods, sometimes labour was given in exchange. Saturday was an unlucky day to transact business. But Wednesday is lucky. Hucksters, pedlars and dealers visited the district in former times and they are still coming. The types of money gone out of use are sovereigns, half-sovereigns and farthings



The wild birds commonly found in the district are the blackbird, swallow, thrush, robin, plover, and many others. Some of the birds migrate in the winter to warm countries. The nest of the swallow is made of balls of clay, mixed with grass and bits of straw. Sometimes it is built in
(continues on next page)

264The cuckoo lays his eggs in another birds nest.Mary MahonyNorthbrook,Kilconnell.



264The colours of the Robin is brown and it has a red breast. How it got its red breast. Long ago the soldiers were crucifying our lord, there was a thorn in our lords head, and the robin went up and pulled it out. It is said that a drop of blood fell on the robins breast.The robin builds its nest in a hole in a ditch. It lays four eggs and their colour is slate.The wren has a brown colour, and it lays fifteen or seventeen eggs. It builds its nest with wool and moss. When the soldiers were crucifying our lord, the robin put moss in all the wounds, and the wren took it to build its nest. That is why the wren is hunted, and is called the devils bird. It builds its nest under the thatch of a house. It covers the nest and leaves a
(continues on next page)

4622966/4618000/4628413.title: Éanlaith Mhara
4622966/4618000/4628413.text:
An Chailleach DubhNil an chailleach dhubh an mhór. Dath dubh air agus brollach bán. Cosa dibha agus gob mór fada.Deanann sé nead as cipiní láidre. Nuair bhionn nead deanta aicí beireann cúig cinn d'uibheacha móra millteach. Teigheann sí ar gor ar feadh míosa nó mar sin. Tagann na héanacha amach aas na h-uibheacha. Bíonn siad an ghránnda mar bíonn clumhach fada ortha.Tugann an téan mhór biagh chuca. Méaduigheann siad annsin agus is gearr go mbeidh siad inann imtheacht as an nead ar fad agus imtheacht leó ina rogha áit.An RoilleachTá an Roilleach an bheag ar fad. Tá dath dubh air agus spotaí bána. Gob gearr agus dath roinnt dearg. Deanann sé nead idir dhá cloic mhór.
(continues on next page)

4622975/4619410/4628503.title: Na hÉisc
4622975/4619410/4628503.text:
Is iomdha cineal eisc sa bhfarraige, atá ainmneacha faoí leith ar chuile cineál díob.Seo cuid de na cineál eisc ata ar eolas sa gceanntar-seo :An langa :Sin é an breach is fearr le n-ithe, acht amhaín an bradán. Iasg geal a bíonn air Cómhnuígeann sé amuig ar an dómhain. Beirtear air go h-iondúil le drúgha agus dríbhán.An Sgadán :Sin breach nach rug ar aon baoidte aríamh. Beirtear air san eangach. San oidhche a beirtear air. Tá sé go han-deas  le nithe núair a bhíonn sé piosa marbuígh.An bradán :Sin é an breach is feárr sa bhfairrge. Iasg dearg a bionn air núair a bíonn sé bruidte. Beirtear air le slat iasgaídh agus le baoidte.

was "Reading made Easy" -  an English text book.  The best pupil was given three pins to be worn for that day.  Slates were used for writing on.Subjects taught were history, geography, arithmetic, writing and Christian Doctrine.  English was the language used except when teaching Christian Doctrine, which was taught through the medium of Irish, the then home language of pupils.There was another Hedge School in Ryehill where a woman taught.  Tradition has it that she experienced great difficulty in getting her pennies from her pupils.



Fox: A man in Killaverin was awakened one night by a noise in his fowl house. When he went out he found a fox lying as if dead. "It's no use disturbing you when you are dead" he said. But in the morning he found that the fox had disappeared.Fairy Hare: There was once a man whose horse was stolen by the fairies. One night while minding a sick cow in the field a hare came and started to suck the milk from the cow. He chased the hare with his hound. The chase lasted so long that the hare started to screech, and the man recalled his dog and let the hare escape. A few days later as the

4622978/4619870/4629384.title: Aoine Chéasta
4622978/4619870/4629384.text:
Ní dheantar aon curaidheacht Aoine Céasta.Tógtar anuas gach ball éadaigh agus gach uile rud eile atá crochta suas agus fágtar ar an mbord nó ar an gcathaoir iad, mar deartar nach ceart aon rud a bheith crochta suas Aoine Céasta.



Deirtear go dtugann an chuac an t-Samraidh léithi i gcomhnaidhe. Dá mbeadhthá sa leaba an céad uair a chloisfeá an chuach, bheadhthá sa leaba ar feadh na bliadhna.Deirtear go gcaillfeadh an chuach le bróid márach a chosa ghránna.

4622999/4622270/4630004.title: Names of Places Round About Us
4622999/4622270/4630004.text:
(continued from previous page)
Shudane. Shudane is so called, because a man named Sodan occupied all the land where the village of Shudane now stands.Tample-Moyle got its name from two roofless churches that are there.Tyasaxon. Tyasaxon is so called because an Englishman lived there and the people called his house Tige Sasanac.Currantarmid got its name from a cairn where a Diarmuid is buried.Tourkeel. Tourkeel is so called because a slender round tower was built there but there is no trace of that round tower to be seen at present.Ballyboggan. Ballyboggan is so called because the land around Ballyboggan is very marshy and soft.Graigabbey. Graigabbey got its name from a Greyabbey which was built there long ago.Ballydavid. Ballydavid is so called because there was a David in every house in that village.

A fox and a wild cat met one day. The fox said that he had several tricks if a hunt came and he said he could run very fast. The wild cat said that he had only one trick that he could run up a tree. Soon a hunt came the cat ran up a tree and was saved and the fox could not run fast enough and was killed. Long ago when the cats were able to talk there lived a woman in Búnán who had one of those cats. One day she was going to wash the churn and she left it on the kitchen floor while she was getting boiling water. Unknown to her the cat jumped into the churn and she came along and poured the boiling water into it. The cat being now scalded jumped up and ran out the door and did not return that day or the next so the woman of the house thought that he had died but he had not. He gathered the cats of the village together and told them that the woman of the house had scalded him on purpose but did not say that he himself had been doing mischief and
(continues on next page)

4623000/4622435/4630517.text:

promised to let him sleep under his cart in the yard. At mid-night he stole the key from the warder and let the priest and captives free then he took off the old clothes and escaped, but they were captured again and put on board a ship. One morning as the soldiers were forcing the priest to say prayers in honour of the king the young men took them and bound them with chains and escaped to Ireland.



The fox is supposed to be a wild dog his colour is red and he has a bushy tail. The old people say that if you cut out a fox's tongue and preserve it in salt for 3 or 4 weeks that it would take out a thorn in any part of your body which would often fail a doctor to do and a lot of people keep foxes' tongues for that purpose. He lives underground in a burrow that he makes himself his food consists of rabbits and all kind of fowl he can capture and during the winter he does a lot of harm.

The badger is a grey spotted animal with a short tail and a mouth and head much resembling that of a pig he also lives in a burrow under the ground. His food consists of the same food as the fox, and if the farmers knows where his burrow is they dig it out and kill this animal. His skin is very valuable it makes splendid furs for the ladies and so do the fox's skin.

4623004/4622841/4630878.title: Animals and Birds
4623004/4622841/4630878.text: Days for Cures. Thursdays and Tuesdays for styes in the eyes. Thursdays and Mondays for  boils. people change into new houses on Fridays. they also start ploughing on Fridays. The people reckon that Friday is also a lucky day to sow crops. It is not right to wash or shear sheep Whit week. It is supposed that it is not right to throw out ashes or to clean out cows beds on May Day. People do not like to get married the third day after Christmas because it is supposed to be the odd Day. There is a cure in the tongue of a fox for a running sore. There is a cure in a dogs lick for a bad cut. It is supposed that there is poisin in an ass's bite or a cat's bite or scrape or a weasal's or a rat's bite. It is supposed that there is a curse on jennets because they do not breed. It is also supposed that rabbits and hares sleep with their eyes opened. It is not right to kill a swan.

4623005/4622882/4631017.title: Animals
4623005/4622882/4631017.text:
Animals There are two kinds of animals tame and wild. Some of them are to be found int he forest while others wander through the fields and bogs. There are a great number of these noticed for they cleverness the fox been one of the cutest.The fox is a red animal about the size of a dog. He has a bushy tail and his fur which is very valuable is sent off and when cured is worn by rich ladies. He lived in a hole in the ground during the day and in the night he wanders out in search of food. He waits until late at night when he steals along and kills the fowl. It is said there is a cure in the foxes tongue for taking out thorns. A story is told about a fox who played a trick on a man. One night a fox visited a fowl house where there were a flock of geese. The only way he
(continues on next page)

19 Eanair 1938Wild AnimalsThe wild animals that live around here are the fox, the rabbit, the hare, the Hedghog the rat and wisel. The fox lives in a den.  He makes his den in a hole in the ground. The rabbit lives in a burrow. He keeps his burrow in a ditch. The hare he lives in long grass and makes a nest there. The Hedghog lives in a hedge. In the month of September he goes in in the hedge rolls himself in grass and moss until spring. The rat lives in a hole in the wall. The fox eats any sort of poultry he can get.The rabbit eats grass and cabbage.The Hare eats grass. The Hedghog. He searches the grass for snails and frogs and eats them.The wisel kills rats and mice and sucks their blood. He also kills young chickens and sucks their blood. The Badger is another and squirell is another animal. He lives in
(continues on next page)

4602712/4597756/4631815.title: Ainmhithe Allta
4602712/4597756/4631815.text:
Seo iad na h-ainmhidhte fiadháin atá in a gcomhnuidhe timhcheall na h-áite seo. An sionnach, an broc, coinín, girrifadh, dóbharchú, easóg, iorraidh ruadh, luch agus frannchach.An SionnachIs mór an rógaire an ainmhidhthe seo. Gníonn sé a lán  dioghbháil sa gceanntar seo. Tagann sé timhcheall na tighthe  san oidhche agus marbhuigheann cearcaí, lachain, geabha, agus sicíní agus tugann sé abhaile  go dtí a pluais iad agus itheann sé iad. Comhnuidheann a lán  sionnaigh - timcheall na h-áite seo. Gníonn siad pluaiseanna in áiteacha uaigneach ins  na coillte, agus ins na portacha. Is ainmhidhe an glic é. Fanann sé in a  bpluais sa lá acht tagann sé amach san oidhche agus's annsin a gníonn sé an dioghbháil. Tá fear in a chómhnuidhe san áit seo agus maidin amháin chuaidh sé amach go'n cró cearc agus fuair sé sionnach in a luighe taobh istigh de'n doras agus cosamhaileacht bás air. Chuaidh sé isteach ann agus do tharraing sé taobh amuigh de'n doras é agus chuaidh sé ar ais do'n teach le gunna fhágháil acht nuair tháinic  sé amach bhí an sionnach imthighthe.An BrocGníonn an ainmhidhe seo pluais dhó féin ins na coilltibh agus  ins na páirceannaibh. Ní'l siad flúirseach timcheall na h-áite. Maireann sé ina bpluais i rith an lae agus tagann sé amach san oidhche le biadh fhágháil. Tá cosamhaileacht mada agus muc air agus tá dath liath air freisin. Codalann sé i rith an gheimhridh agus sabháileann sé féar san samhraidh  agus tógann sé isteach in a bpluais leis é. Is ainmidhe an-crosta é má castar leis san oidhche nó nuair a gortuightear é.
(continues on next page)

The wren hopped on the eagle's back and when the eagle had gone as high as it could he flew up another little bit and he had to be declared king. St. Colmcille knew what the wren had done and he was
