Rabbits live in burrows. They make them in the ground. They make them themselves. They eat young green plants. They do a lot of harm to the farmers crops.   Hares live under a furze bush. They eat young green plants; therefore they do harm also. They eat
(continues on next page)

4811620/4802739/5202897.title: Wild Animals
4811620/4802739/5202897.text:
(continued from previous page)
poison them.Hedgehogs live in hedges and bushes.  They eat leaves and insects.



Once upon a time a fox wanted to get to an island that was out on the bay because he heard fowl calling there and he wanted to get them to eat.  But he could not swim.  He thought of a plan.He lay down on the strand and pretended to be dead.  When the boatman came to go into their boats they saw the fox and
(continues on next page)

4811620/4802741/5202898.title: Story
4811620/4802741/5202898.text:
(continued from previous page)
were on the island.



Rabbits always live in burrows which they make themselves in the ground.  A lot of them gather together and they scrape all the earth with their front paws and throw it back with their hind paws.  They would work away like that until they had a hole like a tunnel made. They always make a lot of holes in the
(continues on next page)

4811620/4802744/5202900.title: Wild Animals
4811620/4802744/5202900.text:
(continued from previous page)
ditches.  He eats young rabbits and young fowl.  He is more good than harm to the farmer.



Once a fox wanted to go out to Bear Island.  He thought of a good plan.  At the same time two men came out to the main land to do some business.  While they were away the fox went down near the boat and he pretended to be dead.  When the men came to the boat they saw the fox near the boat.  They thought that he was dead.  They threw him into the
(continues on next page)

4811620/4802745/5202901.title: Story
4811620/4802745/5202901.text:
(continued from previous page)
boat. When they came to the Island they threw the fox up on the bank. As soon as the fox saw that he was free he ran away as fast as he could. He killed a lot of fowl  He was caught afterwards.



Once a fox went into a hen house.  He went in through the roof.  It was a tatched roof.  When he went in he could not come out.  He thought of a plan.  He pretended to be dead. When the man came out in the
(continues on next page)

4811620/4802746/5202903.title: Story
4811620/4802746/5202903.text:
(continued from previous page)
morning he saw the fox dead, and a lot of hens dead. He caught the fox and threw him outside the door. As soon as the fox was outside the door he arose and ran away. When the man went to bring away the fox, he found that he was gone.



Rabbits live in burrows which they make in the ground.  Most of the rabbits make their burrows in fields.  They
(continues on next page)

4811620/4802756/5202915.title: Cures
4811620/4802756/5202915.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



The children of Glengarriff at preasent know nothing about deer. But their parents would not have that to say. Up to thirty years ago Glengarriff was full of deer. They were supposed to be kept in the demesne but they never were.    The came out by the night and break into the farmer's crops. At first the farmer used to light a fire in one end of the field for the night. But in the end
(continues on next page)

4811620/4802758/5202916.title: The Deer
4811620/4802758/5202916.text:
(continued from previous page)
ground. Then they covered them over with thin sticks and grass. Then when the deer walked on the grass and fell in. One time a flock of deer went trespassing in John Whites place.  He summoned Lord Bantry and they went to count. Lord Bantry swore that he had no control over the deer. From that on, the people could kill them but they did not stop until they killed them all.



Once a deer went trespassing in a
(continues on next page)

4811620/4802760/5202917.title: The Deer
4811620/4802760/5202917.text:
(continued from previous page)
But when the police went up to shoot the dog the man would not let them. When they went back to tell the sergeant and when they came up, the man had the dog hanged to a tree. The tree is still to be seen.



Once upon a time a man lived in Drom Dabhair. He had two farms and a servant boy. One day they were going to have a methell cutting
(continues on next page)

5162142/5158289/5203031.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5162142/5158289/5203031.text:
The fox, the rabbit, the hare, and the badger. The fox does great harm to the farmer. He kills ducks, geese, hens, and turkeys. He makes his den in old dry ruins and in fences. The rabbit makes his burrow in every sort of ground and can do a lot of trespass to crops. He eats oats, young cabbage, and turnips.The hare is seldom seen in the same place and never does much damage.The badger does the same damage as the fox. He lives on the same class of food but is more vicious than the fox.



The weasel is a very vicious animal. He kills rabbits, birds, rats, and mice. It is said that the weasel has knowledge. They are very often seen in this locality. They live in old stone fences and in old ruins. If you pelted stones at a weasel he would try to do you harm.



The stoat is much more common than the weasel, but the people of the locality call both weasel.

5162142/5158290/5203033.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5162142/5158290/5203033.text: One day a farmer was mowing hay in a meadow near his house. He found a nest of young weasels and removed it a little distance away. When the mother weasel came she could find no nest.  As she was searching she found a tincan containing a drink for the farmer. The weasel, thinking that her spit was poisonous, spat into the tin can. She wanted to kill the farmer whom she thought had harmed her young ones. As she was going away she found the nest where the farmer had placed it. When she saw that there was no harm done to the young ones she returned again and spilled the drink, so that the farmer would not drink it.

5162142/5158324/5203104.title: Story about a Weasel
5162142/5158324/5203104.text: A weasel is a very dangerous animal. If anybody pelted a stone at him he would come in the night and kill you.Long ago there was a man mowing hay. He found a weasel's nest and for safety he removed it out of the way. In the evening the mother weasel came home and she could not find her young ones. She went mad around the meadow looking for them. The man had a tincan of milk in the meadow for a drink. The weasel went to it and spat into it so that it would poison them. (The people - T.'03.). At long last she found them and she came back again to the tincan and knocked it and spilled the milk "way" the man would not drink it.

5177649/5176651/5203307.title: Damage or Otherwise of Animals
5177649/5176651/5203307.text:
94Damage or Otherwise of Animals.Hares and rabbits damage corn and young cabbage and turnip plants.Weasel does no damage but hinders multiplication of rats. Supposed to revenge injury and said to kill lambs.Rat- injures corn and roots .Said to be of no benefit.  .Keeps down vermin(creepingMouse -somewhat similiar to rat.Badger -generally harmlessDog -badger would kill lambs if hard pressed for food.Fox -farmer's enemy,Often attacks lambsKeeps down rabbits.Often
(continues on next page)

5215779/5207802/5218470.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5215779/5207802/5218470.text:
Foxes, hares, rabbits, badgers, weasels, and squirrels are found about here. The fox makes it den in a hole under ground. The fox is a very clever animal. It has a bushy tail. It feeds on fowl, and rabbits. Many foxes are killed by dogs and hunters. I often saw a fox haveing a fight with a dog. There is a man liveing near us, his name is Tom Shea and he kills a great number of foxes. He kills one or two foxes very
(continues on next page)

5162135/5157246/5218473.title: Wild Animals
5162135/5157246/5218473.text: The wild animals found in this district are ;- Foxes, Hares, Rabbits, Badgers, Ferrets and Ottors. The fox has his den among the rocks, ottors and rabbits have their den in some old ditch or bank. The badger has his den among the rocks also.The fox eats fowl, and hares and rabbits if he gets them. Hares and rabbits eat green grass and vegetables. The badger also kills fowl and eats them. Badgers are not very plentiful in this district now but foxes are plentiful. The badger is a very dangerous animal he never lets go the leg until he hears the bone cracking.If a child is suffering from whooping cough the best cure,; is to give a ferret milk and the leavings of the ferret is given to the child.

5215779/5207872/5218542.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5215779/5207872/5218542.text:
Foxes rabbits badgers hares weasels squirrels are still to be seen about here. The fox is clever and plays many tricks. He comes to the farmyard at night when the farmer is not out an steals somee fowl and brings them to the young foxes.Then the small and big does have a good feed. He has a big den under ground if you look into the foxes den you will see a big pile of feathers. There is den near our village and therer is a dead fox in it
(continues on next page)

5162142/5158289/5218597.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5162142/5158289/5218597.text:
The fox, the rabbit, the hare, and the badger. The fox does great harm to the farmer. He kills ducks, geese, hens, and turkeys. He makes his den in old dry ruins and in fences. The rabbit makes his burrow in every sort of ground and can do a lot of trespass to crops. He eats oats, young cabbage, and turnips.The hare is seldom seen in the same place and never does much damage.The badger does the same damage as the fox. He lives on the same class of food but is more vicious than the fox.



The weasel is a very vicious animal. He kills rabbits, birds, rats, and mice. It is said that the weasel has knowledge. They are very often seen in this locality. They live in old stone fences and in old ruins. If you pelted stones at a weasel he would try to do you harm.



The stoat is much more common than the weasel, but the people of the locality call both weasel.

5162142/5158289/5218598.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5162142/5158289/5218598.text:
The fox, the rabbit, the hare, and the badger. The fox does great harm to the farmer. He kills ducks, geese, hens, and turkeys. He makes his den in old dry ruins and in fences. The rabbit makes his burrow in every sort of ground and can do a lot of trespass to crops. He eats oats, young cabbage, and turnips.The hare is seldom seen in the same place and never does much damage.The badger does the same damage as the fox. He lives on the same class of food but is more vicious than the fox.



The weasel is a very vicious animal. He kills rabbits, birds, rats, and mice. It is said that the weasel has knowledge. They are very often seen in this locality. They live in old stone fences and in old ruins. If you pelted stones at a weasel he would try to do you harm.



The stoat is much more common than the weasel, but the people of the locality call both weasel.

4922358/4873950/5219132.title: Wild Animals
4922358/4873950/5219132.text: List of wild animals:-Badger, fox, rabbit, hare, rat, mouse, hedgehog, weasel, deer, martin cat, water dogThe hedgehog lives in mossy hedges. The weasel lives in a burrow at the foot of an old wall and there also he has his young. The badger has a den in the land near a rocky place. He roots his den with his paws. The fox often has his den near the badger's. The squirrel makes his nest in a thick branchy tree, or in a hollow tree and covers himself with his tail. The rat lives in an old wall. The mouse lives in old walls or in the walls of old houses. The water dog has his home in a bank beside the river. The martin cat lives in the wood. The rabbit lives in a burrow. The hare lives in a big tuft of grass. This hiding place is called a "form" and it is much the same colour as his fur.

5215779/5207957/5219239.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5215779/5207957/5219239.text:
Foxes, hares, weasels, and squirrels badgers are still to be found in this country. The fox lives under rocks in the wood. The weasels live in holes in walls and old banks. The squirrels live in trunks of trees. The badger lives in holes in the ground. The hares make there beds in whins and rushes. The hare is a very good runer up the hill and when the hounds are after the hare he always runes to the hills. The fox steals fowl from the farm yard and before he comes
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208073/5219442.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5215779/5208073/5219442.text:
Foxes, hares, squirls, rats badgers, weasels, are found in this part of the country. Foxes feed mostel on hens & ducks which they steel from the farmyard. Hares feed on grass and you would see a great many men out hunting them on Sundays. Badgers are very dangerous as they would kill you. When they the a holt of a hand or a foot they wont let it go until they here the boone breaking
(continues on next page)

5215788/5210816/5220250.title: Wild Animals
5215788/5210816/5220250.text:
1. Fox. He  lives on the the mountain and comes down at night to steal fowl. In the fox's tongue there is supposed to be a cure for drawing out a thorn or any other object that got into the flesh.2. Rabbit and hare, live in holes in the ground and are killed and sold by hunters.3. Weasel. People are afraid to rob a weasel's nest, because his spit is supposed to be poison.  One day a man from Bohomore robbed a weasel's nest when he went home he saw a crowd of weasel's outside the window ready to suck his blood.It is said that if any one can get a purse  made of a weasel's skin
(continues on next page)

5215788/5210846/5220313.text:
(continued from previous page)
the young people as they passed up and down the street, to preserve them for another year, until the next season for marrying came. This Thursday got the name of Salting Thursday. The month of May is supposed to be an unlucky month for marrying.

Fox lives up in the mountainRabbit and hare lives in holes in the ground and are killed and sold
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208150/5220764.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5215779/5208150/5220764.text:
Foxes, badgers, hares, weasels & squirrels are found in this part of the country. Hares feed on cabbage & green grass. Long ago a man was out hunting and he saw a hare about two yards away from him. He pointed to the hound with his stick where the hare was. The hound made attempt to catch the hare but it make its excape & soon ran into a sand-pit. It changed itself into a small old woman.
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208231/5221053.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5215779/5208231/5221053.text:
Foxes, hares, badgers weasels and squirrels and rabbits are going around this part of the country. The fox is a very clever animal. There was once a fox and he was very clever. One morning this fox came to a certain man's farmyard and there was a hen house at the back of the house and there was a small window in it. The fox was big and fat and he could hardly get in the window but he pulled himself
(continues on next page)

5215805/5213313/5221534.title: Wild Animals
5215805/5213313/5221534.text:
The wild animals in this place are the goat, the badger, the fox, the hare, the rabbit, the weasel, the lizard and the squirrel. The goat feeds on erbs. He lives in high cliffs and he is a very big animal. People kill goats and use them for food. In the spring the badger gathers a lot of grass and puts it in his burrow for winter. He makes his burrow in the sandybanks. The fox makes his nest under rocks and it is called a den. He kills young lambs and fowl and eats them.
(continues on next page)

5215805/5213415/5221815.title: Wild Animals
5215805/5213415/5221815.text:
There are a number of wild animals on the mountains here namely the rabbit, the hare, the fox, the badger, the goat, and the lizard. The rabbits make burrows with moss and straw. The hares make their nests in the long grass. And the fox makes his nest under the big rocks and it is called a den. The badger makes his nest in the dry banks. The goat sleeps in cliffs and rocks. And the lizard makes his nest in the
(continues on next page)

5215805/5213558/5235288.title: Wild Animals
5215805/5213558/5235288.text:
The animals that live on the mountains here are; the fox, the rabbit, the hare, the badger, and the goat. The fox makes his nest in the rocks. The rabbit makes borrows in sandy-banks. The hare lies in the grass. The badger makes a nest, something smaller than the rabbit and the goat lies on high cliffs. The fox eats young lambs and hens and all sorts of meat. The rabbit eats grass, and the hare eats grass also. The badger
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208436/5235579.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5215779/5208436/5235579.text:
Foxes, hares, badgers, weasels and squirrels are to be found in this district. In the wood behind there is a foxes den. This den is made straight under a limestone quarry and is a great stronghold for the fox. The fox is so clever he always leaves two enterances to his den. Once the people ran a fox into a den. They  closed the enterance air-tight and thought they had
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208607/5235901.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5215779/5208607/5235901.text:
Foxes, hares, badgers, weasels, squirrels, and rabbits are stil found in this cantry. These animals are still found in woods & mountains. Foxes live in dens under ground. The feed on hens and ducks and other fowl. One night a fox went in threw a window in Byrns hen-house and kill all the hens when he went to get out he could not because he had to mush eaten & the window
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208700/5235995.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5215779/5208700/5235995.text:
Foxes, hares, weasels, badgers, rats and squirrels are found in this part of the country. Foxes feed on fowl which they steal from the farmyard. There is a wood below our village and it is full of foxes and hares. The men from our place spend the most of their time hunting the wild animals. Hares feed on grass and cabbage and weasels feed on rabbit's blood which they kill. Sometimes they catch young fowl and drink their blood and stick the chickens in the hole of
(continues on next page)

Tá an bothar ag dúl tridh agus tightar an séan reilig ar on parth ata síos ag an bhfairrghe agus tugta an reilig nua ar an part ata tiobh tuas den bothar
(continues on next page)

Ta an bothar ag dul trun agus tugtar an sean reilig ar an reilig atá sios inaca an farraig. Tá seán seipeal ins an séan reilig. Ta na daoine a bhí Laidte [?] nuair bhí siad ag dul go Albainn

5236081/5228719/5242519.title: Wild Animals
5236081/5228719/5242519.text:
There was lots of wild animals in this country long ago but at the preasant time there are plenty. Such as foxes and rabbits and hares. In this country long ago there was deers and wolves and tigers and lions. They lived in
(continues on next page)

5236081/5228795/5242538.title: Wild Animals
5236081/5228795/5242538.text:
There are not many wild animals in Ireland, but all that are in it are very small. The names of the animals that are in Ireland  rabits he is very small and he has a lot of nice fur on him he is about as big as a cat. he can run fast. People go hunting after them but is very hard
(continues on next page)

5236081/5228848/5243140.title: Wild Animals
5236081/5228848/5243140.text:
There are lots of wild animals such as the ferrit, Some ferrits are tame and more are very wild.WeasalsThe weasals are very dangerous to  have anything to
(continues on next page)

5236081/5228959/5243238.title: Wild Animals
5236081/5228959/5243238.text:
There are lots of wild animals in our village such as foxes, hares, rabbits, weasels. The foxes are very wild and they do a lot of harm they kill hens, ducks, geese, and other animals. also.
(continues on next page)

5235172/5224668/5243644.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5235172/5224668/5243644.text:
Tá roinnt bheag ainmhidhte allta lé fághail sa tír seo go fóill. Bhíodh go leór ainmhidhthe allta lé fhághail ins an ait seo fado ach lé imtheacht aimsire ar a dtugtar an madadh ruad lé fagauil ins an ceanntair seo go fóill.Is é brochaughe a tugtar ar an áit a comnuidheanna an sionnach ann. Is minich a fuair me nead madadh ruadh bíonn sé lé faghail ag taobh carraigh de gnát. Cuireann sé leapaidh uair faoi gach coisis. Bíonn
(continues on next page)

5236081/5229142/5243795.title: Wild Animals
5236081/5229142/5243795.text:
There are lots of wild animals in the country but not so much in this country in other countries around the place a bul is a wild animal. He is not like a cow at all they would kill you if you went anear them much people don't go anear bulls because they
(continues on next page)

5236081/5229203/5243827.title: Wild Animals
5236081/5229203/5243827.text:
There are thousands of wild animals in the world but none what would kill you in Ireland.The lion is the caption of the wild animals. The wild animals in my district are first the fox.The FoxThe fox is the cutest of the wild animals
(continues on next page)

5235179/5225826/5243985.title: Ainmhithe Fiáine: An Luchóg
5235179/5225826/5243985.text:
(continued from previous page)
ar bith san áit sé.Nil sgeal ar bith faoi. Níl aon leigeas san locog.



Comnuideann an easog san isn na claide. Iteann sé cearca agus lacan agus olann sé an fuil. Deanann sé docar san áit seo. Marbuigheann sé cearca agus lacan ar na daoine. Ní deanann sé maitheas ar bith san ait.



Comnuideann an girrfhiadh san cnoc i bpoll itheann sé fear agus gabhaisce. Ní deanann sé docar ar bith san ait. Ní deanann sé maitheas ar bith
(continues on next page)

5236081/5229265/5243993.title: Wild Animals
5236081/5229265/5243993.text:
There are several kinds of animals in all the big woods around the parish. They will not come out much in the day time a tal. A piece of a rabbit is very nice to eat with some potatoes for your dinner. And some soup also. You would
(continues on next page)

5236081/5229324/5244033.title: Wild Animals
5236081/5229324/5244033.text:
There is not as much wild animals in this country as there is in other countries. As there is not as much woods or forests in this country as there are in others. Each wild animal has its own name. These are some of the names,
(continues on next page)

5236081/5229531/5244327.title: Wild Animals
5236081/5229531/5244327.text:
There is a lot of wild animals in this country in the big woods. There is a lot of rats. The rats is not very nice round a house. They are very dirty. They have long tails on them. There is a lot of mice
(continues on next page)

5236081/5229593/5244340.title: Wild Animals
5236081/5229593/5244340.text:
There are not many wild animals in Ireland. The fox is one of them he is very cunning. The fox does a lot of harm he kill all kinds of fowl and young lambs He is about the sizs of a dog. He makes a hole in the wood for
(continues on next page)

5236081/5229746/5244393.title: Wild Animals
5236081/5229746/5244393.text:
The thrush that is a speckled bird who has a very sweet voice. She builds a small nest and lays four eggs in it she lives on worms.The fox that is an animal that does be out in wood he is much like a dog he steals hens
(continues on next page)

5236081/5229807/5244419.title: Wild Animals
5236081/5229807/5244419.text:
Long ago wild animals were common in some places but now they have almost all died away but the foxes are as plentiful as ever. In olden times people could not go out  at all in the night time and very little during  the day because there was
(continues on next page)

5236081/5229855/5244437.title: Wild Animals
5236081/5229855/5244437.text:
There are lots of wild animals. The rabbit is one of those wild animals and the hare and hare and the fox also. The rabbit is a very nice animal he is very small people come hunting out the woods with
(continues on next page)

5236081/5229866/5244440.title: Wild Animals
5236081/5229866/5244440.text:
There are not many wild animals to be found in this country. Those are the most that are to be found the fox is to be found plenty in this country. The fox is much like a bright
(continues on next page)

5236081/5229921/5260284.title: Wild Animals
5236081/5229921/5260284.text:
There is not much wild animals in Ireland nowIn Ireland long a go there was now towns roads field or railwaysThe country was covered with wild animals and foreist
(continues on next page)

5260488/5259539/5263377.title: Wild Animals
5260488/5259539/5263377.text:
The fox is an animal that is round here. Some of them have their dens up in the foot of our hill. More of them have their dens in the glebe. Sometimes they do great destruction on people’s hens. Many a time people used to see a lot of feathers up in the foot
(continues on next page)

5260466/5255216/5264974.text:
Seo iadh na n-ainmheacha atá ar na h-ainmhidhthe allta atá i mo baile fearinn i mbaile na leacan.An madhra ruadh, an broch, an coinín, an girrfid agus an easóg. Déineann an madhra ruadh a leabha i bplús nó síos fé cairrigh mór. An broch. Déineann an broch a leabha i bplús nó uaireannta déineann sé poll ins an dtalamh. Ainmhidhthe
(continues on next page)

5260466/5255302/5265021.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5260466/5255302/5265021.text:
Tá cuidh maith ainmhidhte allta ins an bparoiste seo:- An mada-ruadh, an broc, an girrfhiadh, an coinín, an casóg, agus an iorrad ruadh. Comnuideann an mada - ruadh, agus an broc i bpluais, agus an girrfhiadh i dtor féir, agus an coinín i bpoll fé an  dtalamh, agus an éasógo gcarn cloc, agus an iorrad ruadh ar bhárr crainn nó fé cloic mhóir a béadh ins an fcoill. Déintear

Bhí madha-ruadh ag siubhal in aice abhann lá, agus bhí go leor dreancaidí ag churt air, bhí sé ag iarraidh stop do chur leo. Fe dhéire do ceap sé ar seift. Do fuair sé píosa olna agus

5260445/5253069/5265875.title: Wild Animals
5260445/5253069/5265875.text:
In Patrick Walshe's lake near Chibyhase there is a very remarkable lake where all kinds of wild animals dewell. It is said that fairies are living beneath its waters. Often chariots or wheels were seen around it There used a lot of horses and foals used come out grazing.Once a man caught one of them and tackled her ploughing. When the sun went down in the evening the horse made it to the lake tacklings plough and all There was a big kind of a fish staying in it too. He had
(continues on next page)

5260484/5258514/5266089.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5260484/5258514/5266089.text:
In mó ceanntár féin ta móran ainmidthe allta in a comhnuidhe ann. Tá an gearrfiad an coinín an madadh ruadg an lutogh agus an lutog mor an easog an grainneogh agus an broch. Comnuidheánn an gearrfaid suás ins na sleibte ins an samradh agus ins an geimread ceidheann se síos gó dtí na pairceannaí. Leann an gearrfiadh feir agus coirthe.Comnuidheánn an coinín ins na pairceannaí agus istigh ins na polltai agus itceánn se feir. Níl an coinín doilig rit gó gascá. Níl sé abalta a rith go gasta leis an gearrfiadh. Comnuidheann an
(continues on next page)

5260484/5258567/5266130.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5260484/5258567/5266130.text:
Tá mórán ainmhidhthe alltá ín mo cheanntár féin, agús sé an madadh ruadh an ceann is mo, agus an céann is glíce. Tigheann sé síos ins an oidhche go dtí toigh an fhéirmeorá, agús ís fíor annamh a theidheann sé ‘na ‘bhaile gán chéarc, no lachan, no gé, a bheith léis ar a gréim. Aón uár amháin bhí madhadh ruadh ‘na shuidhe suás ar teach na gcearc agús brís cheann an tóighthe agús tuít sé síos. Chualadh sé carmán féar an toighthe ag teacht ar máidín. Luighe sé siós agús nuaír a tháinig an feár isteach smaointigh sé go rabh an madadh ruadh
(continues on next page)
5260484/5258567/5266130.school_info: School: Sgoil Naoimh Conaill, Na Gleanntaí

5260484/5258586/5266275.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5260484/5258586/5266275.text:
Is iomda beatac alta atá in mo cheanntar-sa. Seo cuid daobta, an madadh ruadh, an madadh uisce, an coinín, an giarrfiadh, an broc, na lucogai beaga, agus na lucogai mora. Comhnuidheann an madadh imeasg na gcnoc. Tá a ait comhnuide aige idir carraigreaca. Tá sé an glic no nuair a teidheann sé isteach sa cro agus nuair a bheas an farradh ro ard bheireann sé greimh ar a rubhall agus teideann sé thart agus thart. Thigheann rae-roilleacan i gcinn na (n-a) n-ean agus tuitheann siad. Annsin marbfuigea
(continues on next page)
5260484/5258586/5266275.school_info: School: Sgoil Naoimh Conaill, Na Gleanntaí

5260484/5258651/5267153.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5260484/5258651/5267153.text: Tá chuid mór ainmhidhthe fiadhain in mo cheanntar sa mhar an coinín, an giarrfiadh, an broch, an tsionnach, an granneóg féir, an madadh uisge, an lucog mór agus bheag, agus an easogh.Comnuidheann an coinín i bpóll in aith uaigneach ins na sleibhthe, an bróc tá a aith comhnuidhe aighe imeasg na sleibhte clocha. An tsionnach tá a teach aige imeasg charraigeacha agus ní fanann sé a bhfad in aith, in a bhfuil a poll teidheann se go aith eighin eile go seachman no bhíonn an toir in a diaidh.
5260484/5258651/5267153.school_info: School: Sgoil Naoimh Conaill, Na Gleanntaí

5260484/5258708/5267224.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5260484/5258708/5267224.text:
San tsean aimsir bhí mórán ainmhidhthe allta san ceanntar seo mar an broch, an giarrfhiad, an cóinín, an grainneóg fheir, an madadh uisge, an madadh ruadh agus an fhiad. (Bhí) Tá an broc iogantach glic agus bheirfead sé leis gach ruda geibheann sé a bheal. Tá sé iongantach láidir. Teidheann an grainneog fheir thart ag cromadaigh roimh dul o sholas. Gnideann an giarrfhiad sgrios mor ar gleasaraí san Geimhreadh. Gnidheann an coinín a pholl comharach do pairc gleasaraí. Itheann sé na gleasaraí sé na gleasaraí nuair a tigeann siad (s) anios.
(continues on next page)
5260484/5258708/5267224.school_info: School: Sgoil Naoimh Conaill, Na Gleanntaí

5260484/5258801/5267309.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5260484/5258801/5267309.text:
In mo ceanntár féin tá morán Ainmidhthe Alltá. Tá an Giarrfiadh, an Bhróch, an Coinín, an Madadh, Ruadh, an Madhadh Uisge, an Locogh agus an Easog. An ghiarrfiadh comhnuidheann sé imeasg na sleibhthe mór ard. Teidheann na daoine amuig ag seilg an giarrfiad agus is iomdha uáir a marbhuigeann siad é.An bhroch comhnuidheann sé ar cnóch ins an Samhradh acht nuair a thigeann an Geimhreadh comhnuuidheann sé imeasg na pairceannaí. Gnideann sé dhochar mór do’n fheirmeoir no is iomda uair a mharbhuigheann sé na beithe.
(continues on next page)
5260484/5258801/5267309.school_info: School: Sgoil Naoimh Conaill, Na Gleanntaí

5260484/5258828/5267364.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5260484/5258828/5267364.text:
Fadh ó shoin bhí Madad ruad ag teacht agus bhí se ag ithe ge. Bhí se ag theachacan oidche a tainigh se bhí na geacha ins an cro. Bhí poll ins an balla agus cuaid se isteach ins an poll. Toisigh se ag ith na geacha agus nuair bi na geaca ithe acha ní tig leis teacht amach. Nuair a thainig an feirmeoia amach un cro' luige se mar bead se marbh. Cuaid an feirmeoir amach le poll a deanam
(continues on next page)

5260484/5258857/5267402.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5260484/5258857/5267402.text:
Tá an cuid seo de’n tír lán de ainmneacha allta, agus ta an tír millte ag cuid aca. Tá ainmneaca an ionganta artha mar tá an madadh ruadh, an broc, an madadh uisge, an easóg, an luchog, an luchóg mhór, an granneóg fheir, an coinín, an giarrfhiadh agus cait fiadhain. Comhnuidheann an madadh ruaidh, an broc, an easóg, an granneóg fheir, an coinín agus an giarrfhiadh imeasg na gcruic fiadhain agus comhnuidheann an madadh uisce ins na Lochannaí agus na h-abainneacha. Tá siad an glic fósta. Ma bhíonn an madadh ruadh gan i mbid tiocfadh sé anuas go cro na cearca agus ma tá na cearca ró ard aige, beirfidh sé grim ar a ruball agus
(continues on next page)

5260484/5258989/5267556.text:
I sleibte Thir Connaill ta moran ainmnide beaga fiadain ann Gnideann cuid acu docar agus gnideann cuid eile acu maith. Bionn an (coinnín) coinini na comnuide i bpoll mor shios faoi an talamh. Tá moran namaidh ag ta an madad ta an feirmeoir agus a gunna Chomhnuidheann an giarrfhiadh ar na cnuic acht ni deaneann se poll ar bhith. Gnideann se rud mar nead ar an talam comhtrom. Gnideann an broc poll imeasg na gcairreaca agus beireann se moran sean fheir go dtí an poll. Nuair ata na broca
(continues on next page)

5260484/5259006/5267609.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5260484/5259006/5267609.text:
In mo ceanntár féin tá morán ainmnidhthe alltá ann. Tá an giarrfhiadh, an coinín, an madadh ruadh, an broch, an lucóg, an lucóg mór, agus an grainneog – féir ann. Comnuidheann an giarrfiadh i measg na (sleib) gchnoch agus codluigheann sé i lag beag no i tomh luachraí. Tigheann se anuas ón na gchnoch ins an Geimhreadh le bhiadh a fhághail. Itheann se cabaisthe agus glasraidh. Comnuidheann an coinínn ins na sleibtibh fósta agus codluigheann se i poll dubh dorca. Itheann se cabhaiste
(continues on next page)

5260463/5254247/5268491.title: Cuigeann
5260463/5254247/5268491.text:
Tá cuigean agam sa mbaile. Tá dath glas ar an cuigean atá agam.  Má bíonn tú ag déanamh an cuigean agus má tainigh duine isteach is ceart aige cuid den cuigean a deanamh, muna deineann sé ní raibh morán im agat.



Níl morán ainmidhe allta san paroiste so act tá an madra ruad, brocaidh, coinín agus girrfidhe ann.  Níl aon diaghbhail ar an coinín agus girrfidhe acht bíonn síad ag ithe fear agus turnipí.  Marbhuigheann an madra
(continues on next page)

Ainmhidhe Allta               Tá alán sort ainmhidhe allta mar atá :-sionnac ,coinín ,girrfidhe agus alán eile .Tá conuidhe ag an sionnac i bpoll fen sliebagus ins an oidhche tagann sé go dtí an feirm agus itheann sé cearca agus lacann agus géana agus tuircí .Itheann sé caoire agus uain comh maith.              Tá cómhnuidhe a an coinín í bpoll fén talamh agus tagann sé go dtí

5260463/5254505/5273913.title: Wild Animals
5260463/5254505/5273913.text:
There are not many wild animals in this parish. The fox, badger, rabbit, hare, and the martin cat. Those animals do much harm to the people, especially the fox. The fox kills lambs, turkeys, geese, hens and ducks, and then he brings them to his den to eat them. The badger is very wicked, but he does bring lambs and fowl like the fox. He eats grass, and digs holes in the ground with his nose to get nuts. He also eats rabbits, The rabbits don't do much harm. They go into gardens by night, and eat cabbage, and oats and wheat. The hare never comes near a house, because he is very wild
(continues on next page)

5260463/5254600/5274097.text:

Blind man's buff is played by putting a cloth around one persons head and eyes. Then the person that was blindfolder has to catch one of the rest. the one that was caught had then to be blindfolded. I knew this myself.



There were many wild animals in the parish such as rabbits, hares, foxes, badgers, rats and weasels. The rabbits destroy land

5274069/5270925/5274146.title: Wild Animals
5274069/5270925/5274146.text: There is a lot of wild animals in Ireland, namely, the rabbit, the rare, the fox and the squirrel.The Rabbit and the Rare, were scarce long ago, but they became very numerous lately, and destroys the farmers vegetables.The Fox lives principally on fowl which he steals from the farmyard.The squirrels food is nuts.

5274069/5270977/5274179.title: Folklore - Wild Animals
5274069/5270977/5274179.text: The names of the wild animals in this district are the Fox, the Badger, the Hare and Rabbit, the Weasil and the Squirrel.The fox steals fowl from the farmyard and eats them.The Badger eats nuts and robs bee's nests.The Hare and Rabbit eats grass.The Weasil drinks blood of small animals and birds and the Squirrel eats nuts.

5274069/5270999/5274193.title: Folklore - Wild Animals
5274069/5270999/5274193.text: The wild animals of this place are the hare, rabbit, fox and badgers. The hare lives in the mountains and makes forms in tufts of heather. The rabbit makes a burrow in the ground in which it lives. The fox makes a burrow in under a big rock and he kills fowl and eats them. The Badger eats roots and it lives under a rock. The hare and the rabbit eats grass.

5274069/5271151/5274331.title: Folklore - Wild Animals
5274069/5271151/5274331.text:
The principal wild animals of this district are the fox, badger, deer, squirrel, rat and the mouse and the weasel. The fox does the biggest damage to the fowl. The badger rutes [?] the ground in search of roots. The squirrel lives on nuts. The rats and mice live on oats an' wheat. The weasel kills young ducks and geese and drinks their blood. The fox is called the red rogue.
(continues on next page)

The badger eats nuts and bees nests . The hare and Rabbit eat grass. The Weasil drinks blood of small animals and birds and the Squirrel eats nuts.Wild Animals

The fox eats fowl it lives usually in a burrow where there is thick undergrowth.The Badger eats roots and it lives under a rock. The Hare and Rabbit eat grass ,the hare lives in a form surrounded by high grass,and the Rabbit lives in a burrow in the ground .The Weasil kills small animals and drinks blood and the Squirrel is to be found among trees

5009086/4985284/5277076.title: The Corncrake
5009086/4985284/5277076.text:
The bee, the bat, the butterfly,The cuckoo, and the swallow,The corncrake put out his beakAnd bid them all good morrow.



Good morning Tom your hens are gone.Your cock shall crow no more.You went to bed you sleep head,And forgot to lock the door.



The cuckoo comes in AprilShe sings her song in May,She hums her tune in the end of JuneAnd in July she flys away.

5274069/5271252/5282738.title: Folklore - Wild Animals
5274069/5271252/5282738.text: 8                20 January 1938.There are a lot of wild Animals in Ireland .              There are rabbits and hare and they cause great trouble to the farmers crops, the food the live grass.          The fox is the king of the wild Animals .In years gone by Fox-Hunting was a favourite sport in Ireland .             The fox's food is geese and other fowl that he steals from the farmland.

5274069/5271381/5282994.title: Folklore - Wild Animals
5274069/5271381/5282994.text: 12              20 th January 1938              Folklore.There is a large number of wild animals in Ireland namely the rabbit ,the hare,the fox, the badger ,the squirrel and the weasel. The rabbit and the hare are the commonest of the wild animals ,they live on grass.     The rabbit especially can do great harm to the farmer by eating the vegetables which grows on the farm. The squirrels food is nuts.

The fox is the cleverest of all the animals ,and often steals a lot of fowl from the farmyard. (continues on next page)

5274069/5271431/5283025.title: Folklore - Wild Animals
5274069/5271431/5283025.text:
3              7th June 1938.                 Folklore.There are a lot of wild animals in Ireland,such as the rabbit, the hare, the fox ,the badger, the weasel.              The rabbit does a lot of harm to the farmer ,he makes burrows in the tillage, and destroys the mangolds, and turnips and potatoes and cuts the oats. The fox is the cleverest animal of the lot, it is very hard to capture him,he watches his chance for the night and he steals fowl
(continues on next page)

5274069/5271484/5283049.title: Folklore - Wild Animals
5274069/5271484/5283049.text:
24th March 1938FolkloreWild animals are not as plentiful now as what they were some time ago.The commonest wild animals in this district at present are the badger, the fox, the deer, the rabbit and the hare.Those animals are not very harmful on the whole but still they do damage enough.The badger and fox kills  fowl, young lambs and kids but they make good sport for the huntsman
(continues on next page)

5235179/5227388/5284356.title: Ainmhithe Fiáine
5235179/5227388/5284356.text:
An Sionnach bhíonn an nead [?] aige sa croch agus ag an fairrge. Bhíonn sé amuig san oidhche ag guid crearcá Deir na sean daoine dhá mbéad dealg i lámh duine agus dhá gcuirfidh teanga na sionnaigh air béadh sé amuigh ar maidin. Sile Ní MorainAn broch Ainmaide beag is sea an broc  Ta sé aongantae láidir agus rín . Bhíonn sé ag ith fatai bhíonn a nead ige sa croch.



An sionnac bhí an sionnac sa croc la agus bhí snechta ar an talam de cuaid an sionnac go dtí an cleadac agus connac se barnac agus cuir sé a teanga faoi an barnac leas an barnac ite agus greamni a teanga  don
(continues on next page)

5286166/5285626/5286192.title: Ainmhithe Allta
5286166/5285626/5286192.text: An coinín; an girrfiadh; an g(h)ráinneog; an easóg; an madra rua; an broc; an teirc ruadh; an dobharcú; an luch; an franncach; an fiadh; an gabhar fiain; an cat fiain.
